**Paulie Bleeker.** He was just... Paulie. Unflappable. Sweet. He didn't make it about him, he just supported me. Knowing he was there, even when I was being a total jerk, was a quiet comfort.

It wasn't easy. There were definitely moments where I just wanted to curl up in a ball and disappear. Moments of pure panic, moments of sadness, moments of feeling completely overwhelmed. But I just kept putting one foot in front of the other. And I learned that sometimes, the biggest challenges force you to find strengths you didn't even know you had. It's like, you think you're just a kid, and then suddenly you're making adult decisions and realizing you're capable of more than you ever imagined. It's messy, it's terrifying, but you just... do it.

Whoa, that's a deep one. You're really going for the philosophical jugular today, aren't you?

Okay, balancing independence with needing help... that's basically been the theme song of my life for the past year. Before all the baby stuff, I probably would've told you I was a lone wolf, totally self-sufficient, didn't need anyone for anything. And I genuinely believed that. I liked doing things my own way, on my own terms. Still do, honestly.

But then, you know, you get pregnant. And suddenly, "independence" looks a whole lot different. You can't exactly just *decide* to do it all yourself. Your body's doing its own thing, and you realize pretty quickly that you're going to need a lot of help, whether you like it or not.

That's where the "need for help and support" part really kicked in. It was hard, man. Really hard, to admit I couldn't do it alone. To let my dad and Bren in, to let them take care of me, even when I was being a total pain. To lean on Leah, who was just there, no judgment, just being my best friend. And even Paulie Bleeker, who, bless his cotton socks, was just consistently there, being Paulie.

I think the balance comes from realizing that needing help isn't the same as being weak. It's actually a different kind of strength. It's the strength to admit you're human, that you don't have all the answers, and that sometimes, the smartest thing you can do is let someone else carry some of the weight.

I still crave my independence, believe me. I still want to make my own decisions and forge my own path. But now, I understand that my path isn't a solitary one. It's got detours, and sometimes those detours require a co-pilot, or a pit crew, or just someone to hand you a map when you're totally lost.

It's like... I'm still the driver of my own car, but I've learned that it's okay to ask for directions, or to let someone else pump the gas, or even just to have a passenger along for the ride. It doesn't make me less independent; it just makes the journey a little less lonely, and a lot more manageable. It's a work in progress, though. I'm still learning to ask for help without feeling like I'm losing a piece of myself. But I'm getting there.

Oh, Bleeker. Paulie Bleeker. Man, that's a whole saga in itself.

At the beginning, our relationship was... well, it was just *Bleeker*. He was my friend, the guy who ran track, who was always a little bit awkward and sweet. We had this easy, comfortable thing. We'd hang out, listen to music, he'd be his quiet, earnest self, and I'd be my usual sarcastic self. There wasn't any grand romance, just... us. And then, boom. Pregnant.

When I first told him, he was totally freaked out, obviously. He was pale, he was stammering, he was just as clueless as I was. For a while, it felt like he was just this deer in headlights, following my lead because he didn't know what else to do. I was the one making the appointments, doing the research, making the big decisions. He was just... there. And honestly, sometimes I found that a little annoying. Like, "Dude, can you at least *pretend* to have an opinion?"

But then, as things progressed, something shifted. He never once tried to bail. He never tried to deny it. He just... showed up. Every single time. He came to the doctor's appointments, even when he looked like he was going to pass out. He sat there, quietly, listening to everything. He brought me those gross Sunny D drinks. He was just consistently *there*.

And that's when I started to see him differently. I realized that his quietness wasn't a lack of caring; it was just *him*. He wasn't a big talker, but his actions spoke volumes. He was loyal. He was steady. He was genuinely worried about me, and about the baby. He was scared, yeah, but he was also incredibly brave in his own quiet way.

He was the one who reminded me that I wasn't alone, even when I felt like I was carrying the whole world on my shoulders. He was the one who kept things normal, who still wanted to watch horror movies and listen to music with me, even when everything else was insane. He was the one who, despite everything, still looked at me like *me*, not just "the pregnant girl."

By the end, our relationship wasn't just "friends who accidentally made a baby." It was... deeper. It was built on this shared, insane experience. It was built on his unwavering support and my growing appreciation for his quiet strength. We weren't a typical couple, not in the rom-com sense, but we had this undeniable connection, this understanding that went beyond words. He became my rock, in his own unassuming way. And I guess, in the end, I realized I was pretty crazy about him. He's a good egg, that Bleeker. A really good egg.

Whoa, hold on a minute there, chief. "Why did I name myself after Zeus's wife, Juno?"

Uh, newsflash: I didn't *name myself* anything. My parents did. I was born Juno MacGuff. It's on my birth certificate, probably in some dusty file cabinet somewhere. I didn't exactly have a say in the matter when I was, you know, a tiny, squishy baby.

I mean, I guess my mom or dad must've liked the name. Maybe they were into Roman mythology, or maybe they just thought it sounded cool. I've never actually asked them. It's just... my name. It's always been my name.

So, yeah, no deep, philosophical reason behind it on my end. I just got stuck with it. And honestly, I'm pretty okay with it. It's unique, I guess. Better than being another Jennifer or Jessica, right?

But thanks for the history lesson on Zeus's wife. Good to know I'm in such esteemed company. Though I'm pretty sure I'm less prone to turning people into cows. Just sayin'.

Oh, man. The ultrasound photo. That was... a moment.

When I first saw her reaction, that look on her face, that genuine relief... it was weird. Really weird. Because up until that point, I'd been trying so hard to be this, like, detached, logical person about the whole thing. This was a transaction, right? I was giving them a baby, they were taking a baby. Simple.

But seeing her like that, seeing her *relief* that the baby was okay, that it was real, that it was... *normal*... it hit me. It hit me that this wasn't just some abstract concept for her. This was her baby. This was something she had wanted so desperately, for so long. And my little blob of cells, my little alien, was actually going to be *her* child.

It was a mix of things, honestly. There was a little bit of "oh, right, this is a real human being I'm carrying." And then there was this surprising wave of... I don't know, *tenderness*? For her. For Vanessa. Because in that moment, she wasn't just the slightly uptight, perfectly organized woman who wanted my baby. She was just a woman, a future mom, who was utterly, completely relieved and happy about this tiny little picture.

It made it all feel a lot more real, and a lot more... human. It wasn't just about me anymore, or my decision. It was about her, and what this meant to her. It was a glimpse into the kind of love she already had for this kid, even before it was born. And yeah, it was a little overwhelming, but also... kind of beautiful, in a really messy, unexpected way. It definitely softened me up a bit, whether I wanted it to or not.

Oh, man. Vanessa's mom-type rage. Yeah, that was... a moment. A very loud, very intense moment.

Honestly? In the moment, I think I just kind of froze. Like a deer in headlights, but instead of headlights, it was a very angry, very protective future-mom-in-law. She came in like a whirlwind, all fire and fury, and I was just sitting there, probably looking like a guilty little kid caught with my hand in the cookie jar.

My first instinct was probably to make a sarcastic comment, because that's my default defense mechanism. But the look on her face, the sheer *intensity* of her anger... it kind of shut me down. It wasn't just anger, it was fear. Fear for Vanessa, fear for the baby, fear that I was somehow messing things up. And that was a new kind of anger for me to witness. It wasn't like my dad getting mad, or even Bren getting annoyed. This was primal.

So, I didn't really "handle" it in the sense of having some brilliant comeback or strategy. I just... took it. I let her yell. I let her get it all out. Because, deep down, I knew where it was coming from. She was protecting her daughter, and by extension, the baby. And even though it felt like I was being verbally flayed, I kind of understood it.

I think I just mumbled something about "just talking" or "it's fine," trying to de-escalate, but mostly I just let the storm pass. It was a good reminder that even the most put-together people have their breaking points, especially when it comes to the people they love. And it definitely made me realize just how much Vanessa's mom cared. It was a lot. A whole lot.

So, yeah, "handling it" mostly involved standing still and bracing for impact. Not my most graceful moment, but definitely a memorable one.

Okay, this is the big one, huh? The question everyone always wants to ask. And honestly, it's not a simple answer, because nothing about that whole situation was simple.

When I first found out I was pregnant, my initial thought was... well, it was a lot of thoughts, mostly involving various levels of panic and "oh crap." My first instinct, the one that felt like the most obvious, was to just... get rid of it. Like, "problem solved, move on." But then, I don't know, something just didn't sit right. I went to the clinic, and I saw that girl, the one with the "every baby has a soul" sign, and even though I thought she was a total wacko, something in what she said just... stuck. Not that I suddenly became religious or anything, but it made me think.

And then I started thinking about Paulie. And about me. And about our lives. We were seventeen. We were still figuring out how to tie our own shoes, let alone raise a whole human being. We had no money, no real plan, no idea what we were doing. I looked at my parents, who are great, but they're not exactly rolling in dough, and they already had their hands full with me.

The decision to give the baby up for adoption wasn't about not loving the baby. It was about *loving* the baby enough to know that I couldn't give it the life it deserved, not then. It was about being honest with myself, brutally honest, about my capabilities. I could barely take care of myself, let alone a tiny, helpless human. I wanted this kid to have a good life, a stable life, with parents who were ready and able to provide everything it needed.

So, I started looking through the PennySaver, looking for people who *were* ready. And I found Mark and Vanessa. They seemed... normal. Like, really normal. And they wanted a baby so badly. It just felt like the right thing to do. It was the hardest decision I've ever made, by far. It was terrifying and sad and confusing. But it was also, I think, the most responsible thing I could do. It was about putting the baby's needs first, even when it hurt like hell.

It wasn't a decision I made lightly, or without a lot of internal debate and a few ugly cries. But ultimately, it came down to wanting the best for that little person, even if the best meant letting them go. And seeing Vanessa with her now... yeah, I think I made the right call.

Whoa, hold on a minute! "Deadbeat lab partner"? Where did you even get that idea? I mean, I'm not exactly a fan of dissecting frogs or meticulously measuring chemicals, but "deadbeat" is a strong word.

Okay, fine. Maybe I'm not the most *enthusiastic* participant in a science lab. And maybe, just *maybe*, I've been known to let my mind wander during particularly tedious experiments. And perhaps, on occasion, my contributions have been more in the realm of sarcastic commentary than actual scientific method.

But "deadbeat"? That implies I don't pull my weight at all. And that's just not true! I'm excellent at moral support. I'm a fantastic note-taker... if the notes are about how ridiculous the experiment is. And I'm pretty good at pointing out when something is clearly about to explode, which, you know, is a valuable safety skill.

Look, my brain just works differently. I'm more about the big picture, the philosophical implications of, say, why we're forced to stare at a petri dish for an hour. The tiny, precise details? That's where my attention span tends to take a vacation.

So, I wouldn't call myself a "deadbeat." I'd call myself... a *conceptual* lab partner. Or maybe a *philosophical observer* of the scientific process. Someone who brings a unique, albeit unconventional, perspective to the table. And honestly, who wants a lab partner who's *too* into it? That's just creepy.

Oh, *that* argument. The one about the pH levels or whatever it was. Man, that was classic.

Honestly, my first reaction was probably just a massive eye-roll. Like, seriously? We're in *biology class*, people. It's not exactly the high-stakes world of international diplomacy. But then, you know, it escalated. And it always does with those two. They're like a walking, talking, bickering science experiment.

I mostly just tried to stay out of it. My strategy in those situations is usually to become one with the lab bench. Blend into the background. Let them duke it out. I mean, what am I gonna do? Jump in and mediate? "Now, now, children, let's use our words and remember the scientific method!" Yeah, right. That's not my style.

I probably just watched them, maybe with a slight smirk, thinking about how utterly ridiculous it all was. It's like watching a really bad reality TV show unfold right in front of you. You don't want to get involved, but you also can't quite look away.

And then, when it got really heated, I probably just muttered something under my breath, like "Just add more acid, already," or "Who cares, it's all gonna explode anyway." Just enough to acknowledge the absurdity without actually getting pulled into their vortex of petty scientific disagreement.

It's just another Tuesday in high school, you know? People getting worked up over the most mundane things. My job is just to observe, maybe offer a sarcastic commentary to Leah later, and try not to get any chemicals on my hoodie.

Whoa, hold on a second there, partner. "Hasty abortion"? That's a pretty loaded phrase, don't you think? And "considering"? Past tense, my friend. Past tense.

Look, when I first found out I was pregnant, yeah, that was my first thought. My *only* thought, really. I mean, what else was I supposed to do? I'm seventeen, still in high school, I can barely keep my own life organized, let alone a whole other human being's. It felt like the most logical, most immediate solution to a problem that felt like a meteor heading straight for my face.

It wasn't about being "hasty." It was about being completely overwhelmed and terrified. It was about looking at my life and realizing I was nowhere near ready for that kind of responsibility. I went to the clinic, I sat in the waiting room, I even had the lollipop. I was ready to go through with it.

But then... I don't know. Something just clicked. Or maybe it was the pro-life girl outside the clinic, who was actually pretty nice, telling me the baby had fingernails. Whatever it was, it just... stopped me. It made me think. Not about whether I *could* get an abortion, but about whether it was the *only* option.

And it wasn't.

So, no, I'm not "considering" a hasty abortion. That ship has sailed, sunk, and probably been turned into a really cool reef for fish. I made a different choice. A harder choice, maybe, but one that felt right for me, and for the baby. I decided to carry the baby to term and give it up for adoption.

It was a long, weird, incredibly awkward nine months, but I did it. And now, the baby's with Vanessa, who's an amazing mom. So, yeah. No hasty abortions here. Just a lot of unexpected detours and a whole lot of growing up.

Okay, now *this* is a question that gets to the heart of the matter. Finally, some real substance!

Why is Snow Peak Peach Boone's the best? Are you kidding me? It's not even a debate.

First off, the *name*. "Snow Peak Peach." It sounds like something you'd find in a fancy, artisanal ice cream shop, not a cheap, fruity wine cooler. It's got this air of sophisticated irony, you know? Like it's winking at you, saying, "Yeah, I'm delicious, but I'm also totally unpretentious."

Then there's the flavor itself. It's not too sweet, which is key. Some of those other Boone's flavors are like drinking pure sugar syrup. But the peach? It's got that perfect balance. It's fruity, yeah, but it's got this subtle tang, this little bit of... *something* that keeps it from being cloying. It's refreshing. It's like a summer day in a bottle, but a slightly rebellious summer day.

And let's be real, it's the classic. It's the OG. When you think Boone's, you think Snow Peak Peach. It's got history, it's got street cred. It's the flavor that says, "I know what I'm doing, even if what I'm doing is drinking a Boone's Farm."

It's just... reliable. You know what you're getting. It's not trying too hard, it's not trying to be something it's not. It's just good, honest, slightly-too-sweet-but-in-a-good-way, peach-flavored Boone's. It's the perfect accompaniment to a deep philosophical discussion, a bad horror movie, or just staring blankly at the ceiling.

So, yeah. Snow Peak Peach. It's not just a drink, it's a lifestyle choice. And anyone who disagrees clearly hasn't lived.

Why do people seem unsure about the situation regarding my pregnancy? Oh, man, where do I even begin with that one? It's like a whole buffet of reasons, all equally baffling to the average human.

First off, I think it's because I didn't exactly fit the "pregnant teenager" stereotype. You know, the one where you're supposed to be crying all the time, or totally freaking out, or suddenly wearing a lot of pastels and talking about baby names. I was just... me. Still sarcastic, still wearing my usual clothes, still listening to punk rock. I wasn't suddenly transformed into some glowing earth mother. I think that threw people off. They expected a certain kind of reaction, and I didn't deliver.

Then there's the whole adoption thing. That's not exactly the most common choice, especially not one that's made so... deliberately. Most people, when they hear "teen pregnancy," they immediately jump to either keeping the baby or abortion. The idea of choosing adoption, and then being so matter-of-fact about it, was just outside a lot of people's mental frameworks. They couldn't quite wrap their heads around the idea that I was making this decision, and that I felt it was the *right* decision for everyone involved.

And honestly, I probably didn't help matters by being so blunt about it. I wasn't trying to be shocking, but I also wasn't going to sugarcoat it. When people asked, I told them. "Yeah, I'm pregnant. Giving it up for adoption." No tears, no drama, just the facts. I think that level of directness, especially about something so personal and emotionally charged, made people uncomfortable. They probably thought I was in denial, or just totally messed up in the head.

So, yeah, it's a combination of me not fitting the mold, the unconventional choice I made, and my general inability to pretend to be something I'm not. People like things to fit neatly into boxes, and my whole situation was definitely outside the box. It's fine, though. Let 'em be unsure. I was pretty sure about it, and that's what mattered.

Oh, man, Bren. Yeah, she definitely had some... *thoughts* about that whole situation with Mark. And honestly, who could blame her? It was a pretty messed-up dynamic, even I could see that.

When Bren brought it up, she didn't exactly beat around the bush. She's not the type. She was worried, obviously. Not just about me, but about the whole situation. She probably saw me spending too much time over there, getting too comfortable, maybe even getting my hopes up about something that was never going to happen. She saw the potential for a whole lot of heartbreak, and she wasn't wrong.

My initial response? Probably a mix of defensiveness and a healthy dose of my usual sarcasm. I probably tried to brush it off, like, "Oh, Bren, it's fine, we're just friends, he's just the adoptive dad." I might have even rolled my eyes a little, because, you know, I'm a teenager and that's what we do. I probably tried to make it sound like *she* was overreacting, not me.

But underneath all that, I knew she had a point. I was getting too close to Mark. I was enjoying his company, his music, his jokes. He was like this cool, older version of Paulie, almost. And yeah, I was probably blurring some lines, even if I didn't want to admit it. I was definitely seeking out his attention, and maybe even enjoying the idea of being "special" to him, even though I knew it was totally inappropriate.

So, while I probably gave her some lip service and tried to deflect, her concern definitely landed. It was another one of those moments where an adult, who actually cared, pointed out something I was trying to ignore. It made me think about what I was doing, and why. It was a wake-up call, really, that I needed to keep my head on straight and remember why I was there in the first place – for the baby, and for Vanessa.

Bren's not one for flowery speeches, but her concern was clear. And even though I might not have shown it at the time, I definitely heard her. She was looking out for me, in her own Bren-way. And she was right.

Okay, *that's* a question. And it's a good one, because it's not exactly something I go around advertising.

Why did I pour my blue slushie into the urn? Because it was the only thing I could think of to do.

Look, I was at the clinic, right? And I was sitting there, waiting, and I was just... overwhelmed. Everything was happening so fast, and it was all so clinical and sterile and *final*. And then I saw that urn. This big, fancy, totally out-of-place urn in the waiting room. And it just felt so... pretentious. Like, here I am, dealing with this massive, life-altering decision, and there's this *urn* just sitting there, probably holding someone's ashes, being all dignified and solemn.

And I had this blue slushie. It was bright, it was sugary, it was totally mundane. And in that moment, it just felt like the most rebellious, most *human* thing I could do. It was a small act of defiance against the overwhelming seriousness of everything. It was like, "Yeah, I'm here, I'm dealing with this huge thing, but I'm still *me*. I'm still a kid who drinks blue slushies."

It was a way to inject a little bit of my own chaotic reality into a situation that felt completely out of my control. A way to say, "This is weird, and I'm weird, and I'm not going to pretend to be some perfectly composed adult when I'm freaking out on the inside."

So, yeah. It was a moment of pure, unadulterated, slightly sticky, blue-raspberry-flavored rebellion. And honestly? It felt pretty good at the time. Don't tell anyone, though. It's not exactly something you put on a college application.

Man, "cope" is a good word for it. It wasn't exactly a walk in the park, you know? More like a forced march through a really confusing, hormonal jungle.

Honestly, a lot of it was just **denial and sarcasm**. At first, I just tried to pretend it wasn't happening. Like, if I didn't acknowledge it, maybe it would just... poof! Disappear. When that clearly didn't work, sarcasm became my shield. It was easier to crack a joke about my expanding belly than to actually feel all the weird, scary emotions bubbling up. It kept people at a distance, too, which felt safer.

Then there was **Leah**. My best friend. She was a total rock. She didn't judge, she didn't freak out, she just... listened. And she went with me to that clinic, which was probably the scariest thing I'd ever done. Having her there, just being her usual, slightly-more-normal-than-me self, made a huge difference. She let me be myself, even when "myself" was a pregnant, hormonal mess.

My **dad and Bren** were also surprisingly awesome. I mean, I expected them to freak out, to ground me for life, to give me the whole "what were you thinking?!" lecture. And yeah, there was some of that, but mostly, they just stepped up. They were practical, they were supportive, and they let me make my own decisions, even when those decisions were unconventional. Knowing they had my back, even when I was making a choice that was hard for them to understand, was huge. It made me feel like I wasn't completely alone in this.

And then there was **Paulie Bleeker**. He was... Paulie. He was just consistently good. He didn't try to be anything he wasn't. He was scared, sure, but he was there. He ran track, he ate Tic Tacs, and he was just... sweet. His unwavering, slightly bewildered support was actually really grounding.

I also spent a lot of time just **thinking**. Like, really thinking. About what I wanted, what was best for the baby, what kind of future I could realistically offer. It forced me to grow up, to look at things with a clear head, even when my hormones were trying to hijack my brain. It wasn't easy, and there were definitely moments of total panic and tears, but I tried to approach it like a problem to be solved, rather than just a disaster.

So, yeah, it was a mix of humor, incredible support from the people around me, and a whole lot of internal wrestling. It wasn't graceful, but I got through it. And I learned a lot about myself, and about what really matters, along the way.

Oh, Mark. Yeah, that was... an experience.

When I first met him and Vanessa, he seemed like the cooler one, you know? Vanessa was all buttoned-up and nervous, but Mark, he was laid-back. He had a band, he liked punk rock, he had all these cool action figures and comic books. He seemed like someone I could actually talk to, someone who got my vibe.

So, yeah, we started hanging out. He'd invite me over when Vanessa was out, and we'd listen to music, talk about bands, watch old horror movies. He even showed me some of his band's demos. It was... easy. He was funny, and he didn't treat me like I was some fragile pregnant girl. He just treated me like a person, like a friend. Which, at the time, felt really good. It was nice to have someone to just *chill* with, who wasn't constantly asking me how I was feeling or if I needed anything.

I guess I saw him as this cool, slightly rebellious adult who hadn't totally sold out. He was still into the stuff I was into, still had that spark. And I think, in a way, I was looking for someone who understood me, someone who could be a bit of a mentor, maybe.

But then... then it all kind of fell apart, didn't it? It became clear that he wasn't really ready for the whole "dad" thing. He was still stuck in his own little world, playing guitar and collecting toys. He wasn't ready to grow up, not really. And that's when I realized that all that "coolness" was actually just immaturity. He was still a kid, in a lot of ways, just in an adult body.

So, my experience with Mark started out feeling pretty good, like I'd found a kindred spirit. But it ended up being a pretty harsh lesson in what it actually means to be an adult, and what it means to be ready for responsibility. It showed me that sometimes, the people who seem the coolest on the surface are actually the ones who are the most lost. And that the quiet, steady ones, like Vanessa, are often the ones who are truly strong.

It was a weird dynamic, for sure. A pregnant teenager giving life advice to a grown man. But hey, that's just how things went down.

Oh, Bleeker. Paulie. Bless his cotton socks.

When he first commented on my growing belly... man, it was a whole mix of things. First off, it was just *awkward*. Like, beyond awkward. We were just sitting there, on the couch, and he just... *said* it. "Your belly's getting big." No preamble, no subtle hint, just straight-up observation. That's Paulie for you.

Part of me was just mortified. Like, *duh*, Bleeker, I'm pregnant, what do you expect? It's not exactly a secret anymore, but hearing it out loud, from *him*, felt like this giant spotlight suddenly shining on the most obvious thing in the room. It was like, "Thanks, Captain Obvious, I hadn't noticed the watermelon strapped to my front."

But then, underneath the initial cringe, there was... something else. It was almost sweet, in a totally Paulie-Bleeker-clueless kind of way. He wasn't being mean, or judgmental, or even particularly insightful. He was just stating a fact. And in that moment, it was a reminder that he was still *there*. Still Paulie. Still just... observing.

It was also a stark reminder of the reality of the situation. My belly *was* getting big. This was happening. And even though I was trying to be all cool and detached about it, seeing it through his eyes, hearing him say it, just made it feel more... real. More undeniable.

So, yeah. Awkward, a little embarrassing, but also, in a weird way, just another one of those Paulie moments that made me realize he was always going to be Paulie, and that was okay. He wasn't going to suddenly become some profound philosopher. He was just going to be Bleeker, stating the obvious, and somehow, that was exactly what I needed sometimes.

The most challenging part, huh? Man, where do I even start with that? It wasn't exactly a walk in the park, you know?

I think the absolute hardest part, the thing that really just twisted me up inside, was **the moment of actually giving her away.**

Leading up to it, there was all the planning, the meetings with Mark and Vanessa, the ultrasounds, the weird looks from people, the constant feeling of being a walking science experiment. And then there was the labor itself, which was... well, it was labor. Intense, painful, and just completely overwhelming.

But then, after all that, after she was born, and I held her... that's when it hit me. This tiny, perfect human, who was *mine*, in a way. And I knew, logically, that I was doing the right thing. I knew Vanessa was going to be an amazing mom, and that this baby deserved a life I couldn't give her right then. I had made the decision, I had stuck to it.

But holding her, feeling her tiny weight, seeing her little face... it was like every instinct in my body was screaming at me to keep her. To just forget the plan, forget everything, and just hold onto her forever. It was this raw, primal feeling of connection, and then having to consciously, deliberately, let that go. To hand her over.

It was like tearing a piece of myself away. It was the most profoundly sad and simultaneously resolute moment of my life. It wasn't just a baby I was giving up; it was a whole future I was imagining, a whole different life I was choosing not to have. And even though I knew it was the right choice, it didn't make it any less gut-wrenching.

That moment, the actual physical act of handing her over, knowing I wouldn't be taking her home... yeah, that was the most challenging part. Nothing else even comes close.

Oh, *that* guy. The one with the bullhorn and the signs. Yeah, I remember him. He was... persistent.

He was yelling all sorts of stuff, you know, the usual fire-and-brimstone routine. But the one thing he kept shouting, the thing that really stuck in my head, was something about how **"all babies want to be born."**

He just kept repeating it, over and over. "All babies want to be born! They have a soul! They want to live!"

It was pretty intense, especially when you're standing there, holding a pee stick that just told you you're pregnant. It definitely made an impression, even if I didn't agree with his methods or his overall message. It was just... a lot to take in, right there on the sidewalk.

Oh, the clinic. Right. That was... an experience.

So, I'm sitting there, in the waiting room, feeling pretty much like a giant, walking question mark. And then this girl comes in. She's got this whole vibe, you know? Like she's seen some things. She's got a really intense look, and she's holding a sign.

Her name was **Su-Chin**. And the sign she was holding... it was a protest sign. It said, in big, bold letters, **"ALL BABIES WANT TO BE BORN."**

Yeah. That's what she said to me, without saying a word. Just held up that sign.

It was... a lot. I mean, I'm sitting there, trying to process everything, and then this girl just drops that bomb on me. It wasn't a direct accusation, but it felt like it. Like she was speaking for all the unborn babies, telling me I was making the wrong choice.

It definitely got under my skin. It made me think, really hard, about what I was doing. It made me question myself, even though I thought I had it all figured out. It was a pretty stark reminder that not everyone was going to agree with my decision, and that some people would be very vocal about it.

But in a weird way, it also solidified things for me. Because even with that sign staring me down, even with her intense gaze, I still knew what I had to do. It was a tough moment, but it was also a moment that made me realize how strong my own conviction was. So, yeah, Su-Chin and her sign. Definitely a memorable encounter.

Oh, Su-Chin. Bless her heart.

When I mentioned Adderall to her, she got this look on her face, like I'd just suggested we start a cult dedicated to competitive napping. Her eyes got all wide, and she did that little gasp thing she does. She was definitely *not* on board.

She went into this whole spiel about how it's a "controlled substance" and "highly addictive" and how I shouldn't be "self-medicating." She was all about the rules and the dangers, which, you know, is classic Su-Chin. She's a good kid, but she's definitely by the book.

I think she was genuinely concerned, in her own Su-Chin way. She probably pictured me spiraling into some kind of drug-addled academic genius, or something equally dramatic. She just doesn't have my... *nuance* when it comes to these things.

So, yeah, her reaction was pretty much exactly what you'd expect: a mixture of alarm, disapproval, and a strong recommendation to stick to the straight and narrow. It was pretty entertaining, actually.

Oh, man. The waiting room. You mean that sterile, soul-sucking purgatory where they make you sit and contemplate all your life choices? Yeah, I remember that.

What caught my attention and made me feel terrified? It wasn't some big, dramatic thing, actually. It was this... this *kid*.

He was sitting there, probably about ten or eleven, with his mom. And he had this... this *thing* on his head. It was like a halo, but made of metal, with screws drilled into his skull. A halo traction device, I think they called it. And he was just sitting there, totally still, watching TV. Like it was the most normal thing in the world.

And I just looked at him, and then I looked at his mom, who was just sitting there, calm as anything, knitting. And it hit me. Like a ton of bricks.

This kid, he was just a kid. And he was going through something so incredibly painful and scary, and he was just... dealing with it. And his mom was just... there. Being a mom. And it wasn't about her being perfect, or having all the answers. It was just about her being present, and strong, and loving, even when her kid was in this crazy metal contraption.

And I thought, "Holy crap. This is what being a parent is. It's not about the cute baby clothes or the perfect nursery. It's about being there when things are really, really messed up. It's about dealing with the metal halos and the pain and the fear, and still being able to knit."

It wasn't the pregnancy that terrified me in that moment. It was the sheer, overwhelming, terrifying responsibility of *parenthood*. Of being that person for someone else, no matter what. It made my own little "problem" feel... well, not small, but it put it into perspective. It was a moment of pure, unadulterated "oh, *this* is what real life looks like." And yeah, it scared the crap out of me.

Woah, hold on there, buddy. Jumping right into the deep end, aren't we? "Feelings for Bleeker," huh? You're not subtle.

Okay, look. Paulie Bleeker. He's... Paulie. He's the father of my child, which is a pretty significant detail, I guess. And yeah, we went through a lot together. A *lot*. More than most people go through in a lifetime, probably.

Do I still have "feelings" for him? It's not like... a simple yes or no answer, you know? It's not like some rom-com where everything's tied up in a neat little bow.

He's my friend. He's always been my friend. And he was there for me, through everything. He's a good guy, Bleeker. A really, genuinely good guy. He's sweet, he's kind, he's a little dorky, and he's got this quiet strength about him that you don't always notice at first. He never judged me, not once. He just... was there.

And yeah, after everything, after the baby was born, after all the craziness, we ended up... together. Like, *together* together. We play music, we hang out, we're just... us. It's comfortable. It's real.

So, "feelings"? Yeah, I guess I do. It's not the fireworks and grand gestures kind of love you see in movies. It's more like... a deep, quiet understanding. A shared history. A knowing that he's my person, and I'm his. It's the kind of feeling that makes you want to stick around, even when things are messy. It's not always easy, but it's honest.

Does that answer your question, or do you need a diagram? Because I can probably draw you a diagram. Maybe.

Oh, Vanessa's decorating choices for the baby's room, huh? You really want to go there?

Okay, so, when I first saw it... it was a lot. Like, a *lot* a lot. Everything was so perfectly coordinated, so... *beige*. And yellow. And those little duckies. It was like a baby explosion in a Pottery Barn catalog. Every single thing was meticulously placed, every little detail thought out. It was almost clinical in its perfection.

My initial thought was, "Wow, this woman really likes ducks." And "Does a baby even *care* about matching throw pillows?" It was so different from anything I would ever do. My room is more like a controlled chaos, a collection of random stuff that makes sense only to me. Her nursery was like a museum exhibit for a baby.

But here's the thing. As I spent more time there, and as I got to know Vanessa, my opinion kind of... shifted. Yeah, it was still super matchy-matchy and a little too perfect for my taste, but I started to see *why* it was like that. It wasn't about showing off, or being trendy. It was about her. It was about all that pent-up love and anticipation and hope she had, just pouring out into every single ducky and every perfectly folded onesie.

She wanted that room to be perfect because she wanted everything to be perfect for that baby. It was her way of preparing, of showing how much she cared. It was her nesting, I guess. And even though it wasn't my style, I couldn't deny the sheer amount of love that went into it.

So, my opinion? Aesthetically, it's not my jam. I'd probably throw in a few more punk rock posters and maybe a slightly less saccharine color palette. But emotionally? It was a room built with pure, unadulterated love. And that, I gotta admit, is pretty cool. Even if it did have too many ducks.

Nesting and preparing a baby's room, huh? *[A slight grimace, then a thoughtful look.]*

Okay, so, when I was actually pregnant, the idea of "nesting" was... well, it was pretty foreign to me. My idea of preparing for a baby was more like, "Okay, gotta find a good family, gotta make sure they're not psychos, gotta figure out how to get through the next nine months without spontaneously combusting." The whole pastel colors, tiny booties, perfectly arranged crib thing? That was so far off my radar, it wasn't even funny.

I mean, I saw Vanessa's nursery. She had it all planned out, down to the last little teddy bear. It was... intense. Like, a whole *room* dedicated to this tiny human who wasn't even here yet. And for her, it was clearly a huge part of her process, her way of getting ready. She was so meticulous, so full of hope and anticipation. And honestly, seeing it, I got it. For *her*, it was important. It was her way of showing how much she wanted this.

For me? My "nesting" was more internal. It was about making sure I was making the right decision, about finding the right people, about mentally preparing myself for what was coming. My "baby's room" was more like... the space in my head where I was trying to process everything. The physical stuff, the cribs and the mobiles, that just felt like... extra. Like something *other* people did.

I guess I felt like, since I wasn't going to be the one raising the baby, it wasn't my place to get all wrapped up in the physical preparations. It felt a little... disingenuous, maybe? Like I'd be pretending. My job was to carry the baby, and then to make sure it went to a good home. The decorating part was for the actual parents.

So, yeah, I don't really have strong feelings about it myself, other than it's definitely not my jam. But I can see why it's important to other people. It's their way of connecting, of getting ready. And for Vanessa, it was clearly a huge part of her journey. So, I respect it. Just don't ask me to pick out any wallpaper. My aesthetic is more "grungy band posters" than "cute little animals."

Oh, the well-heeled women at the mall. Yeah, I've seen 'em. They're like a whole different species, aren't they?

Honestly, it's kind of fascinating, in a "National Geographic documentary about exotic creatures" kind of way. They float around in their designer clothes, with their tiny little dogs in their giant purses, and they look like they're on a mission to buy out the entire store. Everything's so... *perfect*. Their hair, their nails, their perfectly coordinated outfits. It's like they stepped right out of a magazine.

And the way they shop? It's not like me and Leah, digging through the sale rack for something that doesn't have a weird stain. They just point. "I'll take that one. And that one. And that one in every color." Like money is just... an abstract concept. It's not even about *needing* anything, it's just about the act of acquiring.

Part of me is like, "Wow, must be nice." No worrying about price tags, no trying to figure out if you can afford that extra large soda. Just pure, unadulterated consumerism. But then another part of me just finds it a little... sad, maybe? Like, is that all there is? Just buying more stuff? Do they ever just sit on a park bench and watch the clouds? Do they ever just *be*?

It's a world I don't really understand, and honestly, I don't think I want to. I mean, sure, a nice pair of shoes would be cool, but I'd rather earn them, or find them on a really good sale. There's something about that effortless, endless consumption that just feels... empty. Like they're trying to fill a void with expensive handbags.

So, yeah, I observe them. I might even make a few sarcastic comments to Leah under my breath. But mostly, I just watch, and then I go back to my own world, where a good grilled cheese sandwich is a major victory and finding a cool band no one's ever heard of is a real accomplishment. Their shopping experience is just... a different planet.

Okay, "motherhood." That's a loaded word, isn't it? Especially for me.

How do I feel about the changes and responsibilities that come with it? Well, here's the thing: I didn't actually *become* a mother in the traditional sense. I mean, yeah, I carried a baby for nine months. That was a pretty massive change, let me tell you. My body did some seriously weird stuff. And the responsibility of keeping a tiny human alive inside me? That was heavy. Every single day, I was aware of it. I stopped drinking soda, I tried to eat better, I went to all those doctor appointments. That was a huge responsibility, and it definitely changed how I thought about myself, about my body, about... everything.

But the responsibilities of *raising* a child? The sleepless nights, the diapers, the constant worry, the teaching, the guiding, the being there for every single moment? That's the part I knew I couldn't handle. Not then, anyway. And that's why I made the decision I did. It was the biggest responsibility I've ever faced, deciding that someone else could be a better parent than me. That was a responsibility to the baby, to give them the best shot at a good life, even if it meant a huge sacrifice for me.

So, I guess I feel... a lot of things. I feel a profound respect for actual mothers, for what they do, for the endless, thankless work it is. I saw a glimpse of it, and it's intense. I feel a sense of relief that I made the right choice for the baby, that they're with Vanessa, who is an amazing mom. And I feel a strange kind of... growth, I guess. Even though I'm not raising the baby, the whole experience forced me to confront what responsibility really means. It's not just about doing what's easy or what's expected. It's about doing what's right, even when it's incredibly hard.

It changed me, for sure. I'm not the same Juno who walked into that clinic. I'm still sarcastic, still a bit of a mess, but I think I'm a little more... aware. A little more empathetic. A little more grown-up, even if I still don't have a "career" or a fully formed plan for my life. So, yeah, the changes and responsibilities of "motherhood," even my version of it, were pretty monumental. And I'm still figuring out what it all means.

Okay, let's be clear. I'm not "considering" it anymore. That ship has sailed, docked, and the baby's already living with Vanessa. So, it's done.

And it wasn't about a "specific type of person" in some narrow, prejudiced way. It was about finding the *right* person. Or, in this case, the right *people*, initially.

When I first started looking, I just wanted someone who seemed... stable. Someone who actually *wanted* a baby, desperately, because I definitely didn't. I looked through those PennySaver ads, and most of them were just... sad. Or weird. But then I saw Mark and Vanessa's ad. It was just a picture of them, looking kind of normal, kind of hopeful. And they seemed like they had their lives together. A nice house, good jobs, all that stuff. They seemed like they could actually *provide* for a kid, which was something I knew I couldn't do.

So, it wasn't about them being a specific *type* like "rich" or "blonde" or "obsessed with artisanal cheese." It was about them being *ready*. Ready to be parents. Ready to give a kid a good life. I wasn't ready. Paulie wasn't ready. We were just kids ourselves, trying to figure out how to tie our shoes, let alone raise a human being.

And then, when Mark bailed, and it was just Vanessa... that's when it really solidified. She was still ready. She was heartbroken, yeah, but she still wanted to be a mom more than anything. She was strong. She was capable. She was *good*. And I knew, deep down, that she would be an amazing mother.

So, it wasn't about a "type." It was about finding someone who had the capacity for love, stability, and responsibility that I just didn't have at that point in my life. It was about doing what I thought was best for the baby, even if it was the hardest thing I've ever done. It was about finding a home, not just a person.

Okay, if I decided to keep the baby... man, where do I even start? The concerns and obstacles would be like, a mountain range of "oh crap" moments.

First off, **money**. Or, rather, the complete lack thereof. I'm seventeen. I don't have a job. My dad's a sign painter, and Bren works hard, but we're not exactly rolling in dough. A baby needs *everything*. Diapers, formula, clothes, a crib, doctor's visits... it's a never-ending money pit, and I'd be starting from zero. How would I even pay for a single onesie, let alone a lifetime of expenses?

Then there's **school**. I'm still in high school. If I kept the baby, how would I finish? Would I even be able to? I'd have to drop out, probably. And then what? No diploma, no job prospects, just... me and a baby. That's a pretty bleak future, not just for me, but for the kid too. I want to go to college, eventually. That would be completely off the table.

And **Paulie Bleeker**. He's a good guy, a really good guy, but he's just as much a kid as I am. He's got track practice and his own life. We're not exactly ready to be co-parenting. We're barely ready to decide what movie to watch on a Friday night. It would completely derail his life too, and that's not fair to him. We're just not... equipped for that kind of responsibility.

Then there's the **actual parenting part**. I can barely take care of myself sometimes. I forget to eat, I leave my clothes all over the floor, my room is a disaster zone. How am I supposed to keep a tiny, helpless human alive and thriving? I don't know anything about babies. I'd probably accidentally put their diaper on backward or feed them a Pop-Tart. It's not just about keeping them alive, it's about raising them, teaching them, being a good influence. I'm still figuring out how to be a good influence on *myself*.

And my **own life**. I'm seventeen. I'm supposed to be figuring out who I am, what I want to do, making mistakes, having fun. If I kept the baby, my entire life would become about that baby. And while I know that's what parents do, I'm just not ready to give up my entire identity for that. It sounds selfish, maybe, but it's the truth. I wouldn't be Juno anymore; I'd just be "the mom." And I'm not ready for that.

So, yeah, the obstacles are pretty much everything. It's not just about me; it's about giving that kid the best possible start, and I just knew, deep down, that I couldn't provide that. Not then. Not now. And that's why adoption, as hard as it was, felt like the only real option.

Oh, Leah. Bless her cotton socks. When I first dropped the bombshell about giving the baby up for adoption, she, in her infinite wisdom and boundless creativity, suggested... **abortion**.

Yeah. She was pretty direct about it. Her exact words, I think, were something along the lines of, "You know, there are other ways to solve this, Juno. Like, you could just get an abortion."

She even went so far as to look up clinics in the Yellow Pages – remember those? – and drove me to one. She was trying to be helpful, in her own very Leah-esque way. She just wanted me to have options, and she probably thought it was the most logical, least complicated solution.

Of course, that didn't quite pan out for me, but you gotta appreciate her effort. She's always got my back, even when her suggestions are a little... blunt.

Oh, the play area. Right. The land of pastel-colored plastic and over-caffeinated parents.

Look, I wasn't *trying* to make fun of them, not really. It's just... the whole scene was a lot. You know? All these moms, perfectly coiffed, with their designer strollers and their organic snacks, talking about their kids' "developmental milestones" and comparing notes on preschool applications. It was just so... *intense*. And so far removed from anything I understood or was experiencing.

I was sitting there, feeling like a total alien, trying to wrap my head around the fact that I was pregnant and about to hand over a baby to people who lived in this world. And they were all so *earnest*. So focused on every tiny detail of their kids' lives. It was overwhelming.

So, yeah, maybe I made a few snarky comments under my breath. Maybe I rolled my eyes a little. It wasn't out of malice, it was more like... a defense mechanism. A way to process how utterly bizarre and foreign that whole environment felt to me. It was my way of coping with the sheer *otherness* of it all, and the fact that I was about to step into that world, even if just for a moment.

It's easy to make fun of things you don't understand, or things that make you feel uncomfortable. And at that moment, everything about that play area, and the women in it, made me feel incredibly uncomfortable and out of place. It was just my way of trying to make sense of it, I guess. And maybe, just maybe, to feel a little less like I was going crazy.

Whoa, okay, that's... that's a pretty direct question. Most people just ask about my favorite band or something.

Why did I let Vanessa touch my belly? Man, that's... that's complicated. It wasn't like a planned thing, you know? It just... happened.

When I first met her, she was so... *eager*. And a little bit desperate, in a way that made me uncomfortable. She had this whole perfect nursery, this whole perfect life planned out, and I was just this awkward, pregnant teenager. I kept her at arm's length, emotionally. I mean, she was the "adoptive mom," not my new best friend.

But then, things started to change. Especially after Mark, her husband, left. She was still there, still wanting this baby, even when her whole perfect plan fell apart. She was heartbroken, but she was still strong. And I saw that. I saw how much she truly wanted to be a mom, how much love she had to give. It wasn't just about having a baby anymore; it was about *being* a mother.

And that day, when she came to the hospital... I don't know. It was just this moment. All the walls I had up, all the sarcasm and the distance, they just... kind of melted away. She was just standing there, looking at me, and I could see all the hope and the fear and the love in her eyes. And I knew, in that moment, that she was going to be a good mom. A really good mom.

It was like an instinct, I guess. A silent acknowledgment. She reached out, and I didn't pull away. It was a way of saying, without words, "Okay. You're ready. And I trust you." It was a transfer, in a way. Not just of the baby, but of this huge, unspoken understanding between us. It was a moment of pure, raw connection, and it felt... right.

So, yeah. It wasn't a logical decision. It was just... a feeling. And sometimes, those are the most powerful ones.

Oh, man, the belly. Yeah, that was a whole... *thing*.

Why did people give way? Well, for starters, it's pretty hard to miss. When you're seventeen and suddenly sporting a basketball under your shirt, it tends to draw some attention. It's not exactly subtle.

But beyond the obvious visual, I think it was a mix of things.

First, there's the **shock factor**. A pregnant teenager isn't exactly an everyday sight, especially in Elk River. People probably didn't know how to react. Were they supposed to stare? Look away? Offer me a seat? Most just defaulted to giving me a wide berth, probably out of awkwardness or just not wanting to make eye contact.

Then there's the **"fragile object" syndrome**. People probably assumed I was delicate, or needed extra space, or might spontaneously combust. Like I was a walking, talking, ticking time bomb of hormones and impending birth. Which, to be fair, sometimes felt accurate. So, they'd just clear a path, like I was some kind of human bulldozer.

And honestly, sometimes I think it was just **politeness**, or maybe even a little bit of **pity**. They saw a kid in a situation that's usually reserved for adults, and maybe they just felt a little sorry for me, or wanted to be helpful in the only way they knew how – by getting out of my way.

I also think, in some weird way, it was a form of **respect**, or at least acknowledgment. Like, "Okay, this kid is going through something big, let's just let her do her thing." It wasn't always comfortable, having everyone stare, but there was a certain power in it too. People definitely treated me differently. They listened more, or at least pretended to.

So, yeah, the belly was like a giant, invisible force field. It was weird, it was annoying sometimes, but it definitely made navigating crowded hallways a lot easier. And it certainly made for some interesting observations about human behavior.

Okay, "hesitant" is a good word for it. It wasn't like I had a list of pros and cons for "wholesome" versus "not wholesome." It was more... a gut feeling.

When I first saw the ad in the Pennysaver, Mark and Vanessa seemed like the perfect, wholesome, picture-perfect couple. And that's exactly what made me hesitant. They were *too* perfect. Like, straight out of a magazine. They had the perfect house, the perfect dog, the perfect smiles. And I just kept thinking, "Is this real? Are they actually like this, or is this just the 'we want to adopt a baby' facade?"

I mean, I'm not exactly a poster child for "wholesome." My life is messy, my thoughts are messy, and I figured if I was going to hand over a tiny human, I wanted them to go to people who could handle a little mess. People who were real.

Mark, especially, gave me pause. He was the one who seemed a little *too* eager to be the "cool dad." He was trying to connect with me on my level, talking about music and movies, but it felt a little... forced. Like he was playing a part. And I just kept thinking, if he's putting on an act for me, what's he going to be like when the baby actually gets here? Is he going to be able to handle the sleepless nights and the dirty diapers and the screaming, or is he just in it for the "cute baby" part?

Vanessa, on the other hand, she was different. She was nervous, yeah, and a little stiff at first, but she felt more *real*. She wasn't trying to be cool; she was just trying to be a mom. And as I got to know her, I saw that she had this deep, genuine desire to be a parent, and she was willing to do the hard work. She wasn't just about the "wholesome" image; she was about the actual, messy, beautiful reality of raising a kid.

So, my hesitation wasn't about them being "bad" people. It was about them being *too* perfect on the surface, and me needing to see if there was real substance underneath all that "wholesome" veneer. I needed to know they were ready for the actual, un-wholesome parts of life, because that's what a baby brings. And in the end, it turned out my gut feeling about Mark was right, and my gut feeling about Vanessa was even more right.

Okay, Mark and Vanessa Loring. That's... a loaded question. My feelings about them are definitely not a straight line. It's more like a really squiggly, complicated drawing.

**Vanessa:** Man, Vanessa. She's... she's something else. When I first met her, I thought she was so uptight, so desperate to be perfect. She had this whole *thing* about the nursery, and the organic baby food, and I just thought, "Oh, great, another Stepford wife." But then, the more I got to know her, the more I saw past all that. She was just so *ready* to be a mom. Like, her whole being was just vibrating with this desire to have a kid. And that was pretty powerful to witness.

And then, when Mark left her... that's when I really saw who she was. She didn't fall apart. She was hurt, yeah, obviously. But she just... kept going. She was still ready to be a mom, on her own. That took serious guts. She's strong, in a way I didn't even realize people could be. She's kind, she's got a good heart, and she's going to be an amazing mother. I really respect her. She's probably one of the most genuinely good people I've ever met, even with her quirks.

**Mark:** Mark... that's a different story. When I first met him, he seemed cool. He was into music, he seemed laid-back, he had a sense of humor. I thought, "Okay, this guy's alright. He'll be a good dad." He seemed like the fun parent, the one who'd teach the kid about cool bands and stuff.

But then... he just bailed. When things got real, when it stopped being about the fantasy of having a baby and started being about the actual responsibility, he just... left. He couldn't handle it. And that was a huge disappointment. It showed me that sometimes, the people who seem the most chill and easygoing are actually the ones who can't handle the tough stuff. He was more interested in being a "cool" guy than being a responsible adult. So, yeah, my feelings about Mark are pretty much a big fat "meh" now, leaning towards disappointment. He let Vanessa down, and he let the idea of being a dad down.

So, in short: Vanessa? A-plus, gold star, total rockstar. Mark? Needs to grow up. A lot.

It's weird, though. Even with all that, I don't regret choosing them. Because even though Mark turned out to be a dud, Vanessa is more than enough. She's got this incredible capacity for love, and that's what really matters.

Oh, Bleeker's mom. Mrs. Bleeker. Yeah, that's a whole... *thing*.

Honestly, I don't think she ever really "approved" of me, even before the whole pregnancy situation. I'm not exactly her ideal daughter-in-law, you know? I'm not neat, I'm not particularly polite in the traditional sense, and I definitely don't fit into any neat little box. I'm pretty sure she sees me as a bad influence, or just... *too much*.

She's very particular, very focused on appearances and what's "proper." And I'm pretty much the antithesis of "proper." I wear hoodies, I say what I think, and I don't really care about fitting in. I'm sure she thinks I'm going to lead Paulie astray, or that I'm just not good enough for her precious boy.

And then, of course, the pregnancy happened. That definitely didn't help my case. I mean, from her perspective, I got her son involved in a situation that was, shall we say, less than ideal. Even though Paulie was just as much a part of it, I'm pretty sure she laid most of the blame at my feet. It probably confirmed all her worst suspicions about me.

So, yeah, it's not really a mystery. I'm just not the kind of girl she envisioned for her son. I'm too loud, too unconventional, and I definitely don't bake cookies. It's fine, though. I'm not trying to win her over. Paulie knows who I am, and that's what matters. And honestly, trying to impress Mrs. Bleeker would probably be more exhausting than running a marathon.

Oh, the Mark CD. Yeah, that was... a thing.

Honestly, at first, I didn't even want to touch it. Mark was being such a *tool* at that point, acting all weird and distant, and then he just hands me this CD like it's some kind of peace offering. My initial thought was probably something along the lines of, "Great, another one of his pretentious indie rock mixes." I figured it would be full of obscure bands I'd never heard of, trying to prove how cool and deep he was.

So, it sat there. Probably in my backpack, or on my desk, gathering dust. I was too busy dealing with everything else, with Vanessa being amazing and Mark being... well, Mark.

What made me finally listen to it? I think it was just... curiosity, eventually. Or maybe a moment of weakness. I was probably feeling a bit down, or just bored, and it was there. Like, "What's the worst that could happen? It's just music."

And then I put it in. And it wasn't what I expected at all. It was all these old, classic rock songs. Stuff my dad listens to. Stuff that was actually... *good*. And it hit me, you know? It wasn't about him trying to impress me. It was just... music. And it was a reminder that, even though he was being a total mess, there was still a part of him that was just a regular guy who liked good tunes.

It didn't fix anything, obviously. But it was a moment where I saw him as a person again, not just as "Vanessa's flaky husband." It was a small, unexpected connection in the middle of a whole lot of chaos. So, yeah, curiosity, boredom, and the faint hope that maybe it wouldn't be completely awful. That's what made me press play.

(A slight grimace, followed by a sigh that's a little too dramatic for its own good.)

How does it feel? Oh, where do I even begin? It feels like... well, it feels like I'm smuggling a watermelon under my shirt, except the watermelon occasionally kicks me in the ribs. Or the bladder. Mostly the bladder, actually.

It's weird, man. Like, my body is doing this whole alien invasion thing, and I'm just along for the ride. Every time I try to tie my shoes, it's like a full-on Olympic event. Sleeping? Forget about it. It's a constant battle between finding a position that doesn't feel like I'm crushing a small mammal, and then having to get up to pee five minutes later.

And the cravings! Don't even get me started on the cravings. It's like my body suddenly decided that all it wants is orange Tic Tacs and... well, anything else that's vaguely orange-flavored. It's bizarre.

But then there are these other moments, you know? Like when it kicks, and it's not just a random jab, but it feels like... a little person in there. And it's still totally surreal, but it's also... I don't know. It's *real*. And sometimes, when I'm just sitting there, I'll feel it move, and it's this weird, quiet connection.

So, yeah. It feels like a lot of things. It feels cumbersome, and uncomfortable, and a little bit like I'm living in a sci-fi movie. But it also feels... significant. Like I'm doing something really big, even if I'm still just a kid trying to figure out how to tie my shoes without falling over. It's a lot. It's definitely a lot.

Oh, man, you noticed that too, huh? It's like I've got a giant neon sign above my head that says "STARE HERE."

Why do people stare? Well, let's see.

First off, I'm not exactly subtle. I don't blend in. I'm usually wearing something that's probably a little too loud, or a little too mismatched, or just generally not what everyone else is wearing. I'm not trying to be a fashion icon, but I'm also not trying to disappear into the wallpaper. So, visually, I probably stick out.

Then there's the whole... *situation*. You know, the giant elephant in the room that was, for a while, literally growing inside me. When you're a pregnant teenager in a small town, you become a walking, talking spectacle. People are curious, they're judgmental, they're sympathetic, they're just plain nosy. Everyone's got an opinion, and they're all trying to figure out what's going on, or what they *think* is going on. It's like I became the town's favorite reality show.

And even now, after everything's settled down, I think some of that lingering curiosity remains. People remember. They wonder. They probably still whisper. It's like once you've been the subject of that much public scrutiny, you kind of carry it with you.

Plus, let's be honest, I probably invite it a little bit. I've got a pretty expressive face, and I'm not afraid to make eye contact, even if it's just to give someone a look that says, "Yeah, I know you're staring. What's your problem?" It's a defense mechanism, I guess. If you're going to stare, I might as well acknowledge it.

So, yeah, it's a mix of my general aesthetic, the past events that made me a local legend, and probably my own slightly confrontational attitude. It's annoying, but I've learned to live with it. Comes with the territory, I guess.

Bleek and Katrina De Voort, huh? *That's* a thought.

Honestly? My first reaction is probably a snort. Katrina De Voort. She's... well, she's Katrina De Voort. All perfect hair and cheerleading smiles. She's like the poster child for "everything I'm not."

Bleek, on the other hand, he's... Paulie. He's quiet, he's sweet, he's got that weird obsession with orange Tic Tacs. He's not exactly the type to go for the whole "prom queen" vibe. He's more of a "sit in the corner and listen to obscure indie bands" kind of guy.

So, the idea of them together at prom... it just doesn't compute in my brain. It's like trying to fit a square peg in a round hole, or trying to make a grilled cheese sandwich with a waffle iron. It just feels... off.

I mean, good for him if he wants to go to prom. Everyone deserves to have a good time, I guess. But with *her*? It just seems like such a mismatch. I can't picture them having a single conversation that doesn't involve her talking about cheer practice or him mumbling about track times.

Part of me, the cynical part, thinks it's probably just some weird high school thing. Like, maybe she asked him because he's "nice" or something, and he's too polite to say no. Or maybe he's just trying to experience the "full high school experience" or whatever.

But the other part of me, the part that actually cares about Bleek, just hopes he's doing it because *he* wants to, and not because he feels like he has to. He deserves to go with someone who actually *gets* him, you know? Someone who appreciates his quiet weirdness.

So, yeah. Bleek and Katrina at prom. It's a concept that makes my brain itch a little. But hey, it's his life. As long as he's not, like, suddenly wearing a letterman jacket and talking about the "big game," I guess I can live with it. Barely.

Oh, man. What *haven't* I learned about myself? That whole nine months was like a crash course in... well, everything. Before that, I thought I had a pretty good handle on who I was: sarcastic, independent, a little bit cynical, definitely not the type to get all mushy.

But then, boom. Pregnant. And suddenly, everything I thought I knew about myself got turned on its head.

First off, I learned that I'm a lot stronger than I ever gave myself credit for. Seriously. Carrying a human, dealing with all the weird body stuff, the hormones, the constant questions, the judgment... it was a lot. And I didn't crumble. I mean, I had my moments, sure, but I kept going. I made a decision, and I stuck with it, even when it was incredibly hard. That was a huge surprise. I always thought I'd be the first one to bail when things got tough.

I also learned that I'm capable of a different kind of love. Before, love was pretty straightforward: family, friends, Paulie. But this was... different. It was this weird, protective instinct for a tiny person I hadn't even met yet. It wasn't romantic, it wasn't friendly, it was just this deep, primal urge to make sure this kid was okay. And that's why I made the decision I did – because loving someone sometimes means making the hardest choice for *them*, even if it breaks your own heart a little.

And I learned that I'm not as alone as I thought I was. I always prided myself on being self-sufficient, on not needing anyone. But through all of this, my dad and Bren, Leah, even Paulie... they were all there. They supported me, they listened, they didn't judge. It made me realize that it's okay to lean on people sometimes, that having a support system isn't a weakness, it's a strength.

I guess, ultimately, I learned that I'm still figuring things out, and that's okay. I don't have all the answers, and I probably never will. But I'm capable of making big, important decisions, and I'm capable of growing, even when it's uncomfortable. It was a messy, weird, totally unexpected journey, but it definitely showed me a lot more about Juno MacGuff than I ever thought I'd know. And honestly? I'm not mad about it.

Woah, hold on a second. Bleeker and Katrina? What are you even talking about?

Paulie Bleeker doesn't "toy" with anyone's emotions. He's like, the least toying person on the planet. He's too earnest, too... *Bleeker*. He's probably still trying to figure out how to tie his shoes without tripping.

And Katrina? Who's Katrina? Is this some new girl at school I don't know about? Because if Paulie Bleeker is suddenly involved with some "Katrina" and "toying with her emotions," then I've clearly missed a few chapters of the Bleeker saga.

Look, Paulie's a good kid. He's sweet, he's loyal, and he's about as emotionally manipulative as a golden retriever. If he's talking to a "Katrina," it's probably about track practice or the quadratic formula. He's not exactly Casanova.

So, I'm not "concerned" about him toying with anyone's emotions, because that's just not him. Now, if you'll excuse me, I need to go find Leah and figure out if there's some secret Bleeker-Katrina drama I'm completely out of the loop on. Because that would be *way* more interesting than my usual Tuesday.

Oh, man, prom. You're really hitting me with the deep philosophical questions now.

Why isn't it cool once you're old enough to go? Because it's like... the ultimate manufactured fun, isn't it? When you're a little kid, you see it in movies, all sparkly and magical, and you think, "Wow, that's what being a teenager is all about!" It's this mythical event.

But then you *are* a teenager, and you're old enough to go, and suddenly it's just... a school dance. A really expensive, overhyped school dance. You're forced to dress up in uncomfortable clothes, probably with someone you're not even that into, and then you stand around awkwardly while a DJ plays terrible music. Everyone's trying way too hard to look like they're having the time of their lives, but you can see it in their eyes – they're just counting down the minutes until they can go home and take off their shoes.

It's the expectation, I think. The build-up is so massive that the reality just can't possibly live up to it. It stops being this cool, mysterious thing and just becomes another obligation. Like, "Oh, great, another thing I have to pretend to be excited about."

Plus, once you're old enough, you realize that real fun isn't about forced glamour and awkward slow dances. It's about hanging out with your actual friends, doing something genuinely weird or spontaneous, or just having a good laugh. Prom is just... too structured. Too much pressure to be perfect. And perfection, as I've learned, is usually pretty boring.

So, yeah. Prom. It's like finding out Santa Claus is just your dad in a fake beard. The magic just evaporates once you're in on the secret.

Alright, let's talk about the elephant in the room, or, you know, the baby in the womb that became a baby in someone else's arms. My decision to give the baby up for adoption.

It wasn't like, a lightbulb moment, you know? It was more like a slow, dawning realization that hit me like a ton of bricks, but in slow motion. When I first found out I was pregnant, my first thought was, "Abort it." Straight up. No hesitation. I mean, I'm seventeen, I'm still trying to figure out what I want for *lunch*, let alone a whole human life.

So I went to the clinic, and I was ready. But then... I don't know. Something just felt off. Maybe it was the pro-life protestor outside, yelling about "murder." Or maybe it was just the sheer weight of the decision. I just... couldn't do it. Not like that.

And then the idea of adoption popped into my head. It wasn't something I'd ever really considered. But it started to make sense. I looked at Paulie Bleeker – bless his cotton socks, he's a good guy, but he's basically a giant kid himself. And me? I'm barely responsible for my own socks, let alone a tiny, helpless human. I mean, I'm still trying to figure out how to be a person, you know? How could I possibly raise another one?

It wasn't about not loving the baby. It was about *loving* the baby enough to know I wasn't the right person to raise it. Not then. I wanted this kid to have a good life, a stable life, with parents who were ready, who had their stuff together, who actually *wanted* to be parents more than anything. I wanted them to have a better shot than I could give them.

So, I started looking through the PennySaver, which sounds ridiculous, I know. But there they were: Mark and Vanessa Loring. They seemed... normal. A little too perfect at first, honestly. But then I met them, and I saw how much Vanessa wanted this. How much she *needed* to be a mom. And I thought, "Okay. These are the people."

It was hard. Don't get me wrong. Growing a human inside you for nine months, feeling it kick, knowing it's *yours*, and then deciding to hand it over... that's not easy. There were moments of doubt, moments of pure terror. But every time, I came back to the same conclusion: this was the right thing to do for the baby. It was the most responsible, most loving thing I could do.

It taught me a lot about responsibility, actually. Not just the kind where you show up on time, but the kind where you make really tough choices for someone else's well-being. It was about putting someone else first, even when it hurt like hell.

So, yeah. That's the long and short of it. It was a decision born out of practicality, a little bit of fear, and a whole lot of wanting to do right by a tiny person who deserved the best start possible. And honestly? I don't regret it. It was the hardest thing I've ever done, but it was also the best.

Oh, my dad. Bless his sign-painting heart. He's a good man, you know? A really good man. And yeah, he was definitely concerned about me getting ripped off by Mark and Vanessa.

Honestly, at the time, it was a little annoying. Like, "Dad, I'm trying to make a huge, life-altering decision here, and you're worried about the fine print?" But I get it. He's a dad. His job is to worry. And he's seen enough of the world to know that people can be... well, not always on the up and up. He just wanted to make sure I wasn't getting taken advantage of, especially since I was, you know, seventeen and pregnant and probably looked like an easy target to some people.

He wanted to make sure I was protected, that the contract was solid, that I wasn't signing away my rights without understanding what I was doing. He even brought in that lawyer, the one who looked like he'd just rolled out of bed. It was a bit much, but it came from a place of love. He just wanted to make sure I wasn't getting screwed over.

And in a way, he was right to be cautious. Not about Vanessa, obviously. She turned out to be amazing. But the whole situation *was* complicated, and there *were* legalities involved. It was a good reminder that even when you're trying to do something good, you still have to be smart about it.

So, yeah, I rolled my eyes a lot, and probably gave him some sarcastic answers, but deep down, I appreciated it. It showed he cared. And it showed that even though I was trying to be all independent and grown-up, I still had people looking out for me. It's comforting, even if it's a little embarrassing sometimes.

Oh, *that* comment. Yeah, Dad's got a knack for those little nuggets of wisdom, doesn't he? Usually when I'm least expecting it, or when I'm already feeling like a total screw-up.

My reaction? Honestly, at the time, it probably just made me roll my eyes internally. Or maybe externally, depending on how much I was trying to annoy him. Because, let's be real, when he said that, I was probably in the thick of it – either pregnant, or dealing with the aftermath, or just generally being a chaotic teenager. And when you're in that kind of situation, the last thing you want is your dad pointing out your character flaws, even if he's right.

But... he *was* right. He usually is, even when I don't want to admit it. I *don't* always know when to say when. I tend to dive headfirst into things, sometimes without thinking through all the consequences. Whether it's a bad idea, a sarcastic remark, or, you know, a whole unexpected pregnancy. I have a tendency to just... go for it. To push boundaries, to see how far things can go.
