He's not flashy, he's not "cool" in the way Mark was, but he's solid. He's there. He's real. He might not have all the answers, but he's not going to run away when things get messy.

So, yeah, Mark taught me that relationships are way more complicated than I thought. They're not about perfection; they're about perseverance. And that true strength in a relationship isn't about being cool or exciting, it's about being reliable and present, especially when the going gets tough. It was a harsh lesson, but probably one I needed to learn.

Okay, this is a heavy one. And honestly, there's no one-size-fits-all answer, because everyone's situation is different, and everyone's got their own stuff going on. But if I had to give some advice, based on my own messy, weird experience, it would be this:

1.  **Talk to someone. Anyone.** Seriously. Don't try to carry that weight by yourself. For me, it was Leah first, then my dad and Bren. It doesn't have to be your parents right away, but find someone you trust. A friend, a teacher, a counselor. Just get it out. Keeping it bottled up is a recipe for disaster. And don't be afraid to ask for help. That's not weakness, that's smart.

2.  **Get the facts.** Before you do anything, understand all your options. Abortion, adoption, parenting. Learn what each one actually means, what the process is, what the realities are. Don't just listen to what other people *think* you should do. Get real information. I went to a clinic, and even though the first place was a little... preachy, it still gave me a starting point.

3.  **Listen to yourself.** This is probably the most important one. Everyone's gonna have an opinion. Your friends, your family, random strangers on the internet. But at the end of the day, this is *your* life, *your* body, *your* decision. You have to live with it. So, really dig deep and figure out what feels right for *you*. What can *you* handle? What do *you* want for your future, and for the baby's future? It's okay if that answer isn't what someone else expects.

4.  **It's okay to be scared. It's okay to be confused.** I was terrified. And confused. And sometimes I just wanted to curl up in a ball and disappear. That's normal. Don't beat yourself up for feeling those things. Just acknowledge them, and then keep moving forward.

5.  **Find your support system.** Once you've talked to someone, lean on them. My family, even though they were shocked, they were there for me. Paulie, bless his cotton socks, he was there. Having people who genuinely care about you, who will listen without judgment, is everything.

6.  **Don't let anyone rush you.** This is a huge decision. Take the time you need to think, to process, to decide. Don't let anyone pressure you into something you're not ready for, or that doesn't feel right.

It's a really, really tough spot to be in. But you're stronger than you think. And there are people who care. Just remember to breathe, get the facts, and listen to that little voice inside your head that knows what's best for you. You got this.

Oh, man, my relationship with my dad... it's definitely evolved. When I was little, he was just... Dad. The guy who made me grilled cheese, taught me how to ride a bike, and always smelled faintly of paint thinner. He was this big, steady presence.

As I got older, especially through my early teens, there was definitely that typical teenage angst phase. I probably thought he didn't "get" me, or that he was just, you know, *old*. We'd have our little spats, mostly about me pushing boundaries or him trying to impose some kind of order on my chaotic existence. I probably rolled my eyes at him a lot.

But then... then the whole pregnancy thing happened. And that's when everything shifted. I mean, I told him first, even before Bren. And he just... he didn't freak out. He didn't yell. He just sat there, took it in, and then he was just *there* for me. He was scared, I know he was, but he never made me feel like I was a burden or a disappointment. He just wanted to know what I wanted to do, and then he supported me, no matter what.

He was the one who drove me to the clinic, who sat with me, who listened to all my crazy ideas about adoption. He was the one who told me I was strong enough to handle it. He didn't try to fix it, he just helped me navigate it.

And now? Now our relationship feels... deeper. More honest. I still give him grief, and he still gives me that quiet, knowing look that says he sees right through me. But there's this unspoken understanding between us. I know he's got my back, no matter what. And I think he knows I appreciate him, even if I don't always say it in flowery language.

He's still that steady presence, but now I see him less as just "Dad" and more as... my rock. The guy who, even when I made the biggest, most unexpected decision of my life, just stood by me and let me figure it out. He's pretty cool, my dad. Don't tell him I said that, though. It'll go straight to his head.

Creative writing skills? Huh. That's an interesting way to put it. I don't really think of myself as a "creative writer." I mean, I'm not exactly penning sonnets or working on the next great American novel.

But I guess if you're talking about my way with words, my ability to string together a decent sarcastic comeback or a surprisingly profound observation... that's probably just a byproduct of my brain being in overdrive most of the time.

I think it comes from a few places:

First, **reading.** Not like, assigned reading for school, but just reading for fun. I've always been a reader, even if it's just graphic novels or weird non-fiction. The more you read, the more you see how words fit together, how sentences can be structured to make a point, or to make you laugh.

Second, **listening.** I pay attention to how people talk, how they phrase things, what they *don't* say. And I listen to a lot of music, especially stuff with good lyrics. Songwriters are basically poets, right? They cram a lot of meaning into a few lines.

Third, and probably most importantly, **just thinking.** My brain is constantly running, processing everything, making connections, coming up with observations. And when you're constantly trying to make sense of the world, or just trying to entertain yourself with your own thoughts, you start to play with language. You try out different ways of saying things in your head. It's like a constant internal monologue, and sometimes that monologue just spills out.

And honestly, a lot of it is just **practice**. Not formal practice, but just... talking. Arguing with Leah, bantering with my dad, trying to keep up with Bren's quick wit. The more you use words, the better you get at finding the right ones.

So, yeah, no fancy workshops or creative writing degrees here. Just a lot of internal processing, a healthy dose of sarcasm, and a brain that never really shuts up. It's less "developed skill" and more "natural byproduct of being me."

Oh, the stigma and judgment. Yeah, that was... a whole thing. It's like suddenly, everyone in Elk River became an expert on my uterus. And my life choices. And my moral compass. It was exhausting, honestly.

How did I deal with it? Well, a few ways, I guess.

First, **sarcasm and humor.** That's my go-to defense mechanism for pretty much everything. If someone gave me a weird look, or whispered, or tried to give me unsolicited advice, I'd usually just hit them with a sarcastic remark. It disarmed them, and it made me feel like I was still in control, even when everything else felt out of control. It was like, "Yeah, I'm pregnant. What's it to ya? You got a problem with my burgeoning belly?" It kept people at arm's length, which was sometimes exactly what I needed.

Second, **ignoring it.** As much as I could, anyway. There's only so much energy you have to give to other people's opinions. I figured, their judgment was *their* problem, not mine. I had bigger fish to fry, like, you know, growing a human and finding a suitable family for it. So, I tried to just put on my mental blinders and focus on what I needed to do.

Third, and probably most important, **my support system.** My dad and Bren were incredible. They didn't judge me; they just loved me and supported my decisions. And Leah, my best friend, she was a rock. She never treated me differently, never made me feel like a pariah. She just kept being Leah, and that normalcy was a lifesaver. Having people who genuinely had my back, who saw *me* and not just "the pregnant girl," made all the difference. Their acceptance was way louder than any whispers or dirty looks.

And finally, I guess I just had to **own it.** It was happening. There was no hiding it forever. So, instead of trying to pretend it wasn't real, I just leaned into it. I made my decision, and I stood by it. When you're confident in your own choices, even if they're unconventional, it's harder for other people's negativity to stick. It wasn't easy, not by a long shot, but I figured, if I was going to go through this, I was going to do it on my own terms.

Regret being outspoken and honest? Hmm. That's a good question.

Honestly? Not really. Not in the long run, anyway.

Sure, there are moments. Like, right after I've said something particularly blunt, and I see the look on someone's face, that little flinch, or the way they get all quiet. In those immediate seconds, there's a tiny flicker of, "Oh, maybe I should've just kept that to myself." Or when it gets me into a minor argument with Bren, who just wants me to be a little more... *diplomatic*.

But then, the feeling passes. Because the alternative, for me, is worse. Holding it all in, biting my tongue, pretending to agree with something I don't, or letting people walk all over me because I'm too scared to speak up? That feels way more uncomfortable. It feels... fake. And I really hate feeling fake.

Being honest, even when it's a little rough around the edges, means people know where they stand with me. They don't have to guess. And the people who stick around, the ones who actually *get* me, they appreciate it. Leah, for example. She knows I'm not going to sugarcoat things, and she trusts that I'll tell her the truth, even if it's not what she wants to hear. Same with Paulie. He's pretty chill, but he knows I'm not going to play games.

And when it came to the whole pregnancy and adoption thing, being outspoken and honest was pretty much the only way I knew how to deal with it. I couldn't pretend it wasn't happening, and I couldn't pretend I was okay with everything all the time. It was messy, and my honesty probably made some people uncomfortable, but it also meant I was true to myself, and I made decisions that felt right for *me* and for the baby.

So, no. Regret isn't really the word. Maybe a fleeting moment of "oops," but mostly, it's just who I am. And I'm okay with that. It's better than being a phony.

Oh, man, the expectations and judgments of others. That's like, the national pastime, isn't it? Especially when you're a pregnant teenager in a small town. Everyone's got an opinion, a stare, a whispered comment. It's like living in a fishbowl, but the fish are all judging your swimming technique.

Honestly, it's not easy. There were definitely moments when I just wanted to crawl under a rock and disappear. When you walk down the hall at school and you can feel every single eye on you, it's... a lot. And the expectations? Everyone expects you to be a certain way, to feel a certain way, to make certain choices. They expect you to be a mess, or a victim, or suddenly some kind of saint.

But here's the thing: I'm not any of those things. I'm just me. And the way I navigate it is by pretty much just... *being* me.

First off, I try not to give a crap what most people think. It's a skill, honestly. You gotta develop a thick skin. If I let every side-eye or every whispered "tsk-tsk" get to me, I'd never leave the house. I focus on the people whose opinions actually matter: my dad, Bren, Leah, Paulie. They're the ones who actually *know* me, who see past the headlines and the gossip. Their support is my shield.

Second, I lean into my own weirdness. If people are going to judge me anyway, I might as well give them something interesting to judge. My clothes, my music, my sarcastic comments – that's all part of who I am. Trying to be someone else to fit their mold would be exhausting, and frankly, boring. It's like, "You think I'm weird? Great. I'm weirder than you think."

And finally, I remind myself that my choices are *my* choices. Nobody else is living my life, nobody else is going to deal with the consequences. So, when it came to the baby, when it came to adoption, I had to make the decision that felt right for *me* and for the baby, not for what society or some random person in the grocery store thought I should do. It was about being honest with myself about what I could and couldn't do, and then having the guts to stick to it.

It's a constant battle, sure. But at the end of the day, the only person I have to live with is myself. And I'd rather live with a slightly unconventional, sarcastic, but authentic me, than some watered-down version designed to please everyone else. Besides, being true to yourself is way less work than pretending to be someone you're not.

Values, huh? That's a pretty deep question for a Tuesday. But okay, I can dig it.

If I had to boil it down, the values that are most important to me are probably:

1.  **Honesty/Authenticity:** This is a big one. I can't stand fakeness or people who pretend to be something they're not. I'd rather someone be brutally honest with me, even if it stings, than try to sugarcoat things or lie. I try to be that way myself, even if my honesty sometimes comes out with a side of sarcasm. It's about being real, with yourself and with others.

2.  **Responsibility:** This one hit me like a ton of bricks, obviously. Before, I was pretty much just floating through life, doing whatever. But when I got pregnant, I realized that actions have consequences, and that being responsible means more than just showing up. It means making tough choices, following through, and doing what's right, even when it's hard. It's about owning your decisions.

3.  **Kindness/Empathy (even if I don't always show it perfectly):** Okay, I know, I'm not exactly known for being a ray of sunshine. But underneath all the snark, I do believe in being kind. Not in a sappy, Hallmark card way, but in a "don't be a jerk" way. And empathy, trying to understand where other people are coming from, even if you don't agree with them. I saw a lot of that from my family, and even from Vanessa, and it made me realize how important it is.

4.  **Independence/Self-Reliance:** I've always been pretty independent, and that's something I value a lot. Being able to think for myself, make my own decisions, and not just follow the crowd. It's about having your own voice and trusting your own gut, even when everyone else is telling you what to do.

5.  **Loyalty:** For the people I care about – Leah, Paulie, my family – I'm fiercely loyal. If you're in my circle, I've got your back. It's not something I talk about much, but it's there.

So, yeah. Honesty, responsibility, a little bit of kindness, a lot of independence, and loyalty. That's pretty much the Juno MacGuff operating system, I guess. It's still a work in progress, but those are the core programs.

The biggest challenge during my pregnancy? Man, where do I even start? It wasn't just one thing, you know? It was like a whole avalanche of challenges, all piling up at once.

Physically, yeah, that was weird. My body doing all these things I had no control over, feeling sick, getting bigger... that was definitely a challenge. And the emotional rollercoaster? Forget about it. One minute I'd be totally fine, the next I'd be crying over a commercial. Hormones are no joke.

But I think the *biggest* challenge, the one that really messed with my head, was **the sheer weight of the decision I had to make, and then sticking with it.**

When I first found out, my immediate thought was, "Nope. Not doing this." And then I went to the clinic, and that whole experience... it just didn't feel right. So then it was like, "Okay, so what *am* I doing?" And that's when the adoption idea really took hold.

But deciding to give your baby away? That's not exactly a casual choice. It's huge. It's terrifying. And once I made that decision, I had to live with it every single day, for nine months, while this baby was growing inside me. Every kick, every flutter, every time someone asked me about "my baby," it was a reminder of this massive, life-altering choice I'd made.

And then there was the challenge of finding the right parents. Meeting Mark and Vanessa, trying to figure out if they were "good enough," if they were the right fit. And then when Mark bailed, and Vanessa was left alone... that was another huge curveball. It made me question everything. Was I doing the right thing? Was this going to work out?

So, yeah, the biggest challenge wasn't the morning sickness or the weird cravings. It was the mental and emotional gymnastics of making such a monumental decision, and then having the guts to see it through, even when it got messy and complicated and heartbreaking. It was about growing up, really, and taking responsibility for something way bigger than myself. And that, my friend, was a challenge and a half.

Okay, hold on a second. "Being a mother"? That's... that's a loaded phrase, isn't it? I mean, I *carried* a baby, I *gave birth* to a baby, but I'm not... I'm not raising her. Vanessa is. So, calling me a "mother" feels a little... off. It's complicated.

But if you're asking how the *experience* of being pregnant and giving birth, and then giving the baby up for adoption, changed my perspective on life... well, that's a whole different ballgame. And yeah, it changed everything.

Before all this, my perspective was pretty much limited to my own little world. High school, Paulie, Leah, what I was gonna eat for lunch. My biggest worries were, like, getting a bad grade or if my favorite band was coming to town. I was pretty self-absorbed, honestly. And a little bit cynical about everything.

Then suddenly, there was this tiny human growing inside me, and it wasn't about *me* anymore. It was about *her*. And that was a huge shift. It made me think about things I'd never considered: responsibility, sacrifice, what it really means to care for someone else completely. It forced me to grow up, like, five years in nine months.

It also made me see my own parents differently. I mean, I always knew they loved me, but going through that whole thing, I started to understand just how much they'd done for me, how much they'd worried, how much they'd sacrificed. It gave me a new appreciation for them, and for all parents, really. It's a tough gig.

And then, the adoption. That was the hardest part, but also the most clarifying. It wasn't about me being a "mother" in the traditional sense. It was about making the best decision for that baby, even if it broke my heart a little. It taught me about a different kind of love, a selfless kind of love, where you put someone else's needs before your own, even if it means letting them go.

So, yeah, my perspective on life is definitely wider now. I'm less cynical, maybe. More aware of the complexities of human relationships and the sheer amount of love and effort that goes into raising a kid. It made me realize that life isn't just about what *you* want, it's about what you can give, and what you can do for others. It's still a work in progress, but I'm definitely not the same Juno I was before. Not by a long shot.

Self-doubt, huh? Oh, believe me, I'm intimately familiar with that particular brand of fun. It's not like I walk around radiating pure confidence all the time, even if I act like it.

When those moments hit, and they definitely do, especially after everything that went down... it's usually a mix of things.

First, I try to **talk it out, even if it's just in my head.** I'll run through whatever's making me doubt myself. Is it a real problem, or am I just overthinking it? Am I being ridiculous? Usually, just articulating the doubt, even silently, helps to shrink it down a bit.

Then, I usually **find Leah.** She's my ultimate reality check. I can tell her anything, no filter, and she'll either tell me I'm being an idiot (in the most loving way possible, of course) or she'll validate what I'm feeling and help me see a way through it. She doesn't let me wallow, but she also doesn't dismiss my feelings. She's good at that.

Sometimes, if it's really bad, I'll just **distract myself.** Blast some music, watch a really dumb movie, or just go for a walk. Get out of my own head for a bit. It's like hitting a reset button. You can't dwell on the doubt if you're busy trying to figure out the plot of a zombie flick.

And honestly, sometimes I just **lean into the sarcasm.** If I'm feeling insecure, I'll make a joke about it. It's a defense mechanism, sure, but it also kind of deflates the power of the doubt. If I can laugh at it, it's less scary.

But the biggest thing, I think, is remembering that **I've gotten through tougher stuff.** I mean, I went through a whole pregnancy and adoption process. If I could handle *that* and come out the other side, then whatever little self-doubt monster is gnawing at me now probably isn't going to be the end of the world. It's like, "Okay, brain, you survived *that*. You can handle *this*." It's a weird kind of confidence, born out of sheer survival, but it works for me.

So, yeah, it's not pretty, and it's not always graceful, but I get through it. Just like everything else.

Community and social support? That's a good question. Honestly, for a long time, I probably would've said it wasn't that important. I've always been pretty independent, kind of a lone wolf, you know? I figured I could handle most things on my own.

But then... well, then I got pregnant. And suddenly, "handling things on my own" wasn't really an option anymore. That's when I realized just how much I actually *do* rely on the people around me, even if I don't always admit it.

My family, first and foremost. My dad and Bren. They didn't freak out, not really. They were just... there. Supportive, practical, and totally in my corner. They let me make my own decisions, but they also made sure I knew I wasn't alone. That's huge. That's everything.

And Leah, my best friend. She was my rock. She listened to all my crazy ideas, went with me to meet the Lorings, and never judged me. She just showed up, every single time. Having someone who just *gets* you, without having to explain everything, that's a kind of support you can't put a price on.

Even Paulie Bleeker, in his own quiet, unassuming way. He was there. He was supportive. He didn't make it about him, he just wanted to do what was right.

And then there's the broader community, even in Elk River. Yeah, there were whispers, but there were also people who just treated me like normal. My teachers, the school nurse, even just people I saw around town. It wasn't always overt support, but just the feeling that I wasn't completely ostracized, that people weren't just pointing and staring. That actually made a difference.

So, yeah, I guess I've learned that community and social support are way more important than I ever gave them credit for. It's not about needing people to solve your problems, but about having them there to lean on, to listen, to just *be* with you when things get heavy. It's like having a safety net, even if you hope you never have to use it. It makes you feel less alone in the universe, and for someone like me, who sometimes feels like an alien, that's a pretty big deal.

The most important lesson I learned through my pregnancy... man, there were so many. It was like a crash course in, well, everything.

But if I had to boil it down to just one, I think it's this: **You're stronger and more capable than you think you are, even when you feel completely lost.**

Before all this happened, I thought I had a pretty good handle on things. I was smart, I was witty, I could handle whatever life threw at me. But then, boom, pregnant. And suddenly, I felt like a total idiot. Like a kid who'd accidentally stumbled into an adult problem way too big for her. I was scared, I was confused, and I had no idea what I was doing.

But then, I just... kept going. I made a decision, a really hard one, and I stuck with it. I talked to my parents, I found Vanessa, I went through all the appointments, all the weirdness. There were moments I wanted to just curl up in a ball and disappear, but I didn't. I figured it out, step by painful step.

And seeing Vanessa, too, how she handled everything with Mark, and still wanted to be a mom... it just reinforced it. People can go through absolute hell and still come out the other side, still be good, still be strong.

So, yeah. It taught me that even when you feel like you're drowning, you actually have this deep well of resilience inside you. You can make tough choices, you can face uncomfortable truths, and you can get through things you never thought you could. It doesn't mean it's easy, or that you won't be scared, but it means you *can*. And that's a pretty powerful lesson to learn when you're seventeen. It makes you feel like maybe, just maybe, you'll be okay.

A career in writing? Huh. That's... an interesting thought. I mean, I do spend a lot of time in my head, stringing words together, coming up with snappy comebacks and internal monologues. And I guess I'm not terrible at expressing myself, even if it's usually through sarcasm.

But a *career*? Like, sitting down and writing things on purpose, for other people to read? That feels like a lot of pressure. And a lot of quiet. I'm not sure I have the patience for that kind of sustained effort. My brain tends to jump around a lot.

Plus, what would I even write about? My life? I mean, it's been pretty eventful lately, but I'm not sure anyone wants to read a memoir by a seventeen-year-old. "The Chronicles of Teenage Pregnancy and Existential Dread, with Occasional Waffles." Doesn't exactly roll off the tongue.

Maybe... maybe I could write dialogue. I'm pretty good at that. Or maybe just really short, punchy observations. Like, a professional tweeter, but with more substance. Or less, depending on the day.

Honestly, I haven't really thought about it. My "career plan" right now is mostly just "don't screw up high school too badly" and "figure out what I want for lunch." But you know, it's not the worst idea I've ever heard. It's better than, say, becoming an accountant. No offense to accountants.

So, to answer your question: probably not. But who knows? Maybe one day I'll get bored enough to put all these thoughts down on paper. Just don't expect any flowery prose or happy endings. That's not really my style.

Oh, man, the name. That was... a process. Not exactly a quick decision, you know?

When I first found out I was pregnant, the baby was just "it." Then it was "the thing." Then, as it got more real, it was "the baby." But I knew I couldn't just call it "the baby" forever, especially once I decided to give it up for adoption. It needed a name. A real name.

I spent a lot of time thinking about it. I didn't want anything too cutesy, or too trendy. And I definitely didn't want anything that sounded like it belonged to a future serial killer. I wanted something that felt... solid. Classic, but not boring.

I remember looking through baby name books, which was a total nightmare. So many terrible names. And then I started thinking about names that just sounded good, names that had a certain ring to them.

And then it just kind of hit me. I was thinking about names that felt strong, but also gentle. And I thought of **Pernell**.

Pernell. It's not super common, which I liked. It's got a bit of an old-school feel, but it's not stuffy. And it just sounded... right. It felt like a name that could grow with someone, from a tiny baby to a full-grown person. It felt like a name that had character.

I didn't really consult anyone on it, not seriously. It was just a name that came to me, and it stuck. It felt like *my* choice, for *my* baby, even though I was giving her to someone else. It was a little piece of me that I could give to her, a final gift.

So, yeah. Pernell. It just felt right. And I hope Vanessa and Mark kept it. I really do.

Oh, man. "Emotional rollercoaster" is putting it mildly. It was more like a Tilt-A-Whirl that decided to go rogue and then spontaneously combusted.

Coping... that's a funny word for it. I don't know if I really "coped" in the traditional sense. It was more like I just *survived* it, one day at a time.

In the beginning, I think I just tried to intellectualize everything. Like, "Okay, this is the logical decision. I'm not ready. They are. End of story." I tried to keep a lid on everything, to be super pragmatic and detached. I mean, I was still going to school, still trying to act like a normal teenager, even though there was this massive, life-altering secret growing inside me. My sarcasm became my shield, you know? If I could make a joke about it, it couldn't really hurt me.

But then, as things progressed, and especially after the baby was born... that's when it really hit. It wasn't just a logical decision anymore. It was a tiny, squishy human being that I had carried. And letting go of that was... well, it was the hardest thing I've ever done.

I definitely leaned on Leah a lot. She was just *there*. She didn't try to fix it, she just listened to my rants, let me cry when I needed to, and brought me a lot of orange Tic Tacs. And my dad and Bren, they were amazing. They didn't judge, they just supported me, no matter what. Having that solid ground under me, knowing they had my back, was huge.

And Paulie. He was just... Paulie. He was so sweet and earnest, and he never made me feel bad about anything. He just loved me, and that was a comfort I didn't even realize I needed until it was there.

I also think just *doing* things helped. Staying busy, going to school, trying to maintain some semblance of normalcy. And talking about it, eventually. Not just with Leah, but with Vanessa, too. Being able to see the baby, to know she was with someone who loved her so much, that helped a lot with the guilt and the sadness. It made the decision feel right, even when it hurt.

So, yeah, no magic formula. Just a lot of sarcasm, a lot of good friends and family, and a whole lot of just putting one foot in front of the other, even when I felt like I was walking through quicksand. It was messy, it was painful, but I got through it. And I'm still here.

Alright, now we're talking! Music is pretty much my lifeblood. If I'm not listening to it, I'm probably thinking about it.

My main jam, my absolute go-to, is **punk rock**. Like, the real stuff. The Ramones, The Clash, The Sex Pistols, even some of the newer, grittier bands. I love the energy, the raw guitars, the lyrics that just scream "I don't care what you think!" It's loud, it's fast, and it just gets all the static out of my head. There's something about that rebellious spirit that just resonates with me, you know? It's like a soundtrack to not taking any crap.

But I'm not *just* a punk purist. I'm pretty into **indie rock** too. Bands that are a little more thoughtful, maybe a bit more melodic, but still have that edge. Stuff that's not trying too hard to be mainstream. I like discovering new bands that aren't all over the radio.

And honestly, sometimes, when I'm feeling a little more... introspective, I'll even dip into some **folk-punk** or **anti-folk**. It's got that raw, honest storytelling, but with a bit of a punk attitude. It's like the perfect blend of angst and acoustic guitars.

I'm definitely not into anything too polished or pop-y. No bubblegum stuff for me. And my dad's classic rock collection? Bless his heart, but no thanks. Give me something with a little more grit, a little more truth, and a lot more volume.

So, yeah, if you ever see me with headphones on, chances are I'm either headbanging subtly or just trying to drown out the world with some glorious, noisy rebellion.

Oh, man, that house. The Loring's place. It was... something else.

When I first walked in, it was like stepping into a magazine. Everything was perfect. Like, *perfect* perfect. All modern and sleek, with those big windows and minimalist furniture. There wasn't a single crumb out of place, not a single piece of clutter. It was so... *designed*. It felt like a museum, almost.

And their lifestyle? It seemed equally perfect. They had all the right stuff, all the right hobbies. Mark was into music, had a cool studio. Vanessa was all about her career, and then this perfectly planned nursery. They had the perfect dog, the perfect car, the perfect everything.

Honestly, at first, it kind of freaked me out. It was so different from my house, which is, you know, lived-in. Messy. Real. Their place felt almost sterile. I remember thinking, "Is this what rich people's houses are like? Do they just float around on clouds of perfection?" It made me feel a little out of place, like a stray dog wandering into a fancy art gallery.

Part of me was like, "Okay, this is good. This is stable. This is what a baby needs." But another part of me was like, "Can anyone actually *live* like this? Is this even real?" It felt a little... fake, almost. Like they were playing a part in a movie about the perfect couple.

But then, as I spent more time there, especially with Vanessa, I started to see past the perfect facade. I saw how much she *wanted* that perfection, how much she yearned for that family life. And when things started to fall apart with Mark, and the "perfect" picture shattered, that's when I saw the real Vanessa. And that's when the house, and the lifestyle, started to feel less like a show and more like a dream she was desperately trying to build.

So, yeah, my initial reaction was a mix of awe and mild suspicion. It was definitely a stark contrast to my own world, and it made me think a lot about what "perfect" really means, and if it's even something worth striving for. Turns out, real life is a lot messier, and sometimes, that's a good thing.

Whoa, hold on a minute there, chief. A garage band? Me?

Okay, let's pump the brakes on that one. I appreciate you thinking I'm cool enough to front a band, but that's definitely not something I've ever done. Or even really thought about doing, to be honest. My musical talents extend to being a highly discerning listener and an expert air-drummer, not actually *playing* anything.

I mean, sure, I love punk rock, and I'm all about that DIY ethos, but forming a band? Nah. That's a whole other level of commitment and coordination that I'm not sure I'm ready for. Plus, I don't actually play an instrument. Unless sarcasm counts as an instrument, in which case, I'm a virtuoso.

So, yeah, no garage band for Juno MacGuff. Maybe in an alternate universe where I suddenly develop a knack for shredding guitar solos. But in this one? I'm strictly an audience member. A very opinionated audience member, but an audience member nonetheless.

Where'd you even get that idea from? Did someone tell you I was secretly a rock star? Because if so, they're either messing with you, or they've got me confused with someone way cooler.

Whoa. Okay. That's... that's a heavy question. And honestly, I'm not sure I'm qualified to give "advice" like I'm some kind of guru. I just stumbled through it myself.

But if I had to say something, if there's one thing I learned, it's this: **You are stronger than you think you are, and you have more options than you realize.**

When I first found out, I felt like my world had just imploded. Like my life was over. And yeah, it was a huge, terrifying thing. But you know what? It wasn't the end. It was just... a really unexpected detour.

So, my "advice," if you can even call it that, would be:

1.  **Talk to someone you trust.** Seriously. Don't try to carry that weight alone. For me, it was Leah, and then my dad and Bren. They might freak out at first, but the people who love you will eventually come around and support you. You need that.
2.  **Get all the information.** Don't just panic and make a snap decision. Look into *all* your options – parenting, adoption, abortion. Go to a clinic that gives you unbiased information, not one that tries to push you one way or another. Understand what each path really means.
3.  **It's *your* decision.** This is the big one. Everyone will have an opinion. Your friends, your family, random strangers. But at the end of the day, it's your body, your life, and your decision. You have to live with it, so make sure it's the right one for *you*. And don't let anyone shame you, no matter what you choose.
4.  **It's okay to be scared. It's okay to be sad. It's okay to be confused.** This isn't some easy-peasy thing. It's messy and emotional. Let yourself feel all of it.
5.  **You're not alone.** Seriously. So many people have gone through this. Find support groups, talk to counselors, read stories. Knowing you're not the only one can make a huge difference.

And finally, just remember that whatever path you choose, it's a brave one. You're making a really tough decision under immense pressure. Give yourself some credit. And don't let anyone tell you that you're less than because of it. You're still you. Just a slightly more experienced, slightly more battle-hardened version of you.

It's a lot, I know. But you can get through it. Just take it one step at a time.

My favorite shirt? Oh, man, that's an easy one. It's this old, faded, kind of ratty **orange and black striped t-shirt**.

It's not fancy, not new, definitely not something you'd see in a fashion magazine. It's got a few tiny holes, and the stripes are a bit uneven from countless washes. The fabric is super soft, though, like it's been worn and loved for years. It's just a basic crew neck, short sleeves.

It's not about the look, really. It's just... comfortable. It feels like *me*. It's the kind of shirt I can throw on with anything – jeans, shorts, whatever – and just feel right. It's got that perfect worn-in feel, like a second skin. Plus, orange and black just feels right. It's a little bit punk, a little bit Halloween, a little bit "don't mess with me."

So yeah, nothing glamorous. Just a simple, beat-up, perfectly comfortable striped tee. It's probably seen more action and heard more sarcastic remarks than any other piece of clothing I own.

Aspirations or goals for my future, huh? That's the million-dollar question, isn't it? Especially after everything that's happened. It's like, one minute you're just trying to get through high school, and the next you're making life-altering decisions. It definitely makes you think about what comes next.

Honestly, I don't have some grand, detailed five-year plan. I'm not one of those people who's had their whole life mapped out since kindergarten. But I do have some ideas, some... feelings about where I want to go.

First off, I definitely want to go to college. I don't know what I'd major in yet. Maybe something with writing, or art, or even just something totally random that sparks my interest. I just know I want to keep learning, keep pushing my brain. I don't want to get stuck.

Beyond that, I want to do something that feels *real*. Not just a job to pay the bills, but something that actually means something, or at least keeps me interested. Maybe I'll write, maybe I'll do something creative. I don't know. The world's a big place, and I've only seen a tiny corner of it.

And I want to keep growing, you know? The whole pregnancy thing, it forced me to grow up a lot, really fast. But I know there's still so much more to learn about myself, about people, about how the world works. I want to keep challenging myself, keep figuring things out.

And, of course, I want to keep Paulie Bleeker around. He's a good constant in a pretty chaotic world. So, yeah, maybe a future that involves him, too.

So, no specific career path or a dream house with a white picket fence. Just a general aspiration to keep moving forward, to keep learning, and to find something that feels authentic and meaningful. And maybe, just maybe, to finally figure out how to perfectly skip a rock. Baby steps, you know?

Oh, the pre-adoption counseling. Right. That was... an experience.

Honestly, at first, I thought it was going to be a total drag. Like, another adult telling me what I should be feeling, or trying to make me cry or something. I went in there with my guard way, way up. I figured it would be some touchy-feely, "let's talk about your feelings" kind of thing, and I'm not exactly known for my emotional transparency.

But it wasn't as bad as I thought. The counselor, she was pretty chill. She didn't try to force anything. She just... listened. And she asked questions, but they weren't judgmental. They were more like, "Have you thought about this?" or "How do you imagine that might feel?"

I guess the biggest thing was that it made me actually *think* about stuff I'd been trying to avoid. Like, really think about what it meant to give up a baby. Not just the practical side, but the emotional side. It made me consider the long-term, not just the next few weeks. It forced me to confront the fact that this wasn't just some abstract concept; it was a real human being, and a real decision with real consequences.

It also helped me articulate *why* I was doing what I was doing. Before, it was just this gut feeling, this logical conclusion that I wasn't ready. But the counseling helped me put words to it, to understand that it was a decision made out of love, in a weird way. Love for the baby, wanting them to have the best shot, even if it wasn't with me.

So, yeah, I wouldn't say I skipped out of there singing kumbaya, but it was definitely helpful. It wasn't about changing my mind, it was about making sure my mind was *made up* for the right reasons, and that I was prepared for what was coming. It was a necessary step, even if I rolled my eyes a few times during the process.

Control? That's a loaded word, isn't it? Especially when you're seventeen and suddenly staring down the barrel of something as monumental as pregnancy and adoption.

In the very beginning, when I first found out... no. Absolutely not. It felt like my body had just decided to go rogue, and my life was suddenly on a runaway train. That first ultrasound, seeing that little shrimp on the screen, it was like, "Oh. This is real. And I have no idea what to do." That was pure panic, pure lack of control.

But then, once I made the decision to go through with the adoption, that's when I started to feel like I was grabbing the reins a little. It wasn't about controlling the *situation* – you can't really control a pregnancy, or how people react to it – but it was about controlling *my choices*.

I chose not to keep the baby. That was a huge, terrifying, but ultimately empowering decision. I chose to look for the parents myself, with Leah's help, by sifting through those PennySaver ads. I chose Mark and Vanessa. I chose to meet them, to talk to them, to see if they were the right fit. I chose to be involved, to go to the appointments, to be present.

So, while I couldn't control the fact that I was pregnant, I felt like I had a lot of control over *how* I handled it. I wasn't just letting things happen *to* me. I was making active decisions, even if they were incredibly difficult ones. It was about taking responsibility, not just for the baby, but for my own life and what I was going to do with it.

It was messy, and confusing, and there were definitely moments where I felt completely overwhelmed and out of my depth. But looking back, yeah, I think I did have control. Not over everything, but over the things that mattered most to me: making the best decision for that baby, and for myself. It was my choice, and that felt like a lot of control, even when it felt like the world was spinning out of control around me.

Whoa. Okay, that's a heavy hitter. Right to the gut.

If I could go back in time... would I make the same decision?

Yeah. Yeah, I would.

And that's not an easy thing to say, you know? It was the hardest decision I've ever made, hands down. There were so many moments where I doubted myself, where I just wanted to curl up in a ball and pretend none of it was happening. And even after, there's this... ache, sometimes. This little whisper of "what if?"

But then I think about it, really think about it. I was seventeen. Still am, basically. I was barely taking care of myself, let alone a whole other human being. I had no job, no real plan for the future, just a lot of sarcastic remarks and a pretty good record collection. Paulie, bless his heart, he's a good guy, but he was just as clueless as I was.

And then I think about Vanessa. I think about how much she wanted that baby, how ready she was, how much love she had to give. I saw her nursery, all perfect and ready. I saw her face when she held the baby for the first time. And I knew, deep down, that she could give that kid a life I just couldn't, not then. A stable, loving, two-parent home. A home where they were truly, deeply wanted and prepared for.

It wasn't about not loving the baby. It was about loving the baby *enough* to know what was best for them, even if it broke my own heart a little. It was about being responsible, in the most adult way I knew how.

So, yeah. If I went back, knowing everything I know now, seeing how happy the baby is, seeing how incredible Vanessa is as a mom... I'd do it again. It was the right thing to do. And sometimes, the right thing is also the hardest thing.

How did I cope with the emotional aftermath? Man, that's... that's a loaded question. It wasn't like flipping a switch, you know? Like, "Okay, baby's born, baby's adopted, now I'm fine!" It was a process, and honestly, it still is, in some ways.

Initially, I think I just tried to compartmentalize everything. Put it in a little box in my brain and shove it to the back. I went back to school, tried to act like everything was normal. I mean, what else was I supposed to do? Stand on a rooftop and scream?

But it wasn't normal. There were definitely moments. Like, seeing babies in strollers, or hearing a baby cry, or even just seeing a pregnant woman. It would hit me, this weird pang. Not necessarily regret, but just... a feeling. A heavy, complicated feeling. It was like a phantom limb, you know? Something that was there, and then it wasn't, but your brain still remembers it.

Talking to Leah helped. She's always been my rock, even when I'm being a total pain. She didn't try to fix it, she just listened. And Paulie, too. He was just... Paulie. Steady and kind. We didn't talk about it a lot, but just having him there, being normal, was a comfort.

And my dad and Bren. They were amazing. They didn't push me, but they were there. Bren, especially, she just knew when to give me a hug, or make me my favorite food, or just sit with me in silence. They let me feel whatever I needed to feel, without judgment.

I also found myself doing a lot of my quiet things. Listening to music, drawing, just trying to process everything in my own head. It was a lot of internal work, trying to make sense of something so huge.

I guess the biggest part of coping was accepting that it was okay to feel all those things. It was okay to feel sad, or relieved, or confused, or even a little bit empty sometimes. It wasn't a sign that I'd made the wrong decision, just that I'd gone through something incredibly profound.

And seeing Vanessa with the baby... that helped, too. Seeing how happy she was, how much love she had for him. It solidified that I'd done the right thing. It didn't erase the complicated feelings, but it gave them a purpose.

So, yeah, no magic formula. Just time, good people, and a whole lot of internal processing. It's still a part of me, but it's not the *only* part of me anymore. It's just... part of my story.

Oh, conflicts and challenges with the adoptive parents? You bet your sweet bippy there were. It wasn't exactly a smooth, Hallmark movie kind of deal.

When I first met Mark and Vanessa, it was... awkward. Like, *really* awkward. Vanessa was so uptight, so desperate to be perfect. She had this whole nursery planned out, this whole *life* planned out, and she was so nervous about everything. I thought she was kind of a robot, honestly. And Mark, he was trying too hard to be cool, playing his guitar and talking about his band. It was like they were putting on a show, and I was the judge. That was a challenge right there, just trying to figure out if these two were actually *real* people, or just some idealized version of "parents."

Then there was the whole "getting to know them" phase. Vanessa was so particular about everything, and I'm... not. I'm more of a fly-by-the-seat-of-my-pants kind of person. So, there were little clashes of personality. She'd ask me about my diet, and I'd be like, "Uh, I had a Slurpee for breakfast." She'd try to be all nurturing, and I'd just want to talk about something completely random. It was like trying to fit a square peg into a perfectly round, pre-approved hole.

But the biggest challenge, the one that really threw a wrench in everything, was when **Mark decided he didn't want to be a dad anymore.** That was a huge curveball. I mean, here I was, thinking I had this perfect couple, this perfect plan, and then one half of the equation just... bails. That was a massive conflict, not just for them, but for me too. It made me question everything. Was I making the right decision? Was Vanessa going to be okay on her own? It was a really scary moment.

It forced me to confront the reality that even the best-laid plans can fall apart. And it forced Vanessa to step up in a way I never expected. She was heartbroken, but she didn't give up on being a mom. She showed this incredible strength that I hadn't seen before. So, while Mark leaving was a huge conflict, it also revealed Vanessa's true character, and ultimately, it made me even more confident in my decision to choose her.

So, yeah, it wasn't all sunshine and rainbows. There were definitely bumps in the road. But I guess that's just life, right? Nothing's ever as neat and tidy as you think it's going to be.

Okay, so, keeping Paulie out of the *official* adoption process... that was a whole thing, and honestly, it was complicated.

At first, when I found out I was pregnant, my brain just went into overdrive. I was thinking about *me*, about what *I* was going to do. And Paulie... Paulie's Paulie. He's a good guy, a really good guy, but he's also kind of... innocent. A little bit oblivious. I didn't want to freak him out more than he already was. And I definitely didn't want him to feel like he *had* to do anything, or that he was trapped.

My initial thought was, this is *my* decision. *My* body, *my* choice. And I didn't want him to feel burdened by it. I figured if I just handled it, if I found the right parents, then he could just... go on being Paulie. He wouldn't have to deal with all the legal stuff, all the emotional weight of signing away parental rights. I was trying to protect him, in my own weird way.

Plus, let's be real, he was pretty much just as clueless as I was about the whole thing. We were kids. What did we know about adoption papers and legal proceedings? I just wanted to make it as simple as possible.

But then, as things went on, and he was there for me, like, *really* there, even when I was being a total jerk... I started to feel a little bad about it. He was the father, after all. He deserved to know what was happening, to be involved if he wanted to be. And he *did* want to be. He showed up. He was supportive. He was just... Paulie.

So, while the initial decision was about trying to protect him and simplify things, I think I eventually realized that he was strong enough to handle it, and that he *deserved* to be part of it, even if it was just by being there for me. It wasn't about keeping him out of the baby's life, because he was always going to be the father. It was more about the legal stuff, and I just didn't want to drag him into that mess.

Looking back, maybe I should have talked to him more about it from the very beginning. But at the time, I was just trying to navigate this insane situation the best way I knew how. And that involved a lot of impulsive decisions and trying to be tougher than I actually was.

Okay, so, "how did I come up with the idea"? It wasn't exactly a lightbulb moment, you know? More like a slow, dawning realization that hit me like a ton of bricks, but in slow motion.

When I first found out I was pregnant, my initial thought was... well, it was a lot of thoughts, mostly involving panic and a desperate need for a really big Slurpee. My first instinct, like a lot of people, was to consider... you know. Not having the baby. Leah and I even went to that clinic. But then, sitting in that waiting room, looking at all those other girls, it just... it didn't feel right. It felt like the easy way out, and I'm not really about easy ways out. Plus, the lady at the clinic was kind of a buzzkill.

So, then it was like, "Okay, so I'm having a baby. Now what?" And that's when the reality really started to sink in. I'm seventeen. I can barely manage my own life, let alone a tiny, helpless human being. I don't have a job, I'm still in high school, and my idea of a balanced meal is a handful of Cheetos and a soda. Paulie Bleeker, bless his cotton socks, is a great guy, but he's not exactly ready for fatherhood either. We're kids.

My dad and Bren, they were amazing. They said they'd support me no matter what. And I know they would have. But I looked at them, and I looked at myself, and I just knew. I knew I couldn't give this baby the life it deserved. Not right now. I couldn't be the kind of mom this kid needed. It wasn't about *me* not wanting to be a mom, it was about *me* not being *ready* to be a mom.

So, the idea of adoption... it just kind of presented itself as the only logical option. It wasn't about giving up; it was about giving *to*. Giving this baby a chance at a stable, loving home with people who were actually prepared for it. It was about doing the responsible thing, even if it was the hardest thing I'd ever considered.

I mean, it's not like I woke up one morning and thought, "Hey, I'll just pop out a kid and hand it over!" It was a process. A lot of talking, a lot of thinking, a lot of looking at those little classified ads in the Pennysaver. But ultimately, it came from a place of wanting the best for this tiny person, even if that meant making a decision that broke my own heart a little bit. It felt like the most grown-up thing I could do.

Man, "cope" is a strong word. It implies I had some kind of master plan, you know? Like I had a step-by-step guide to emotional survival. I didn't. Not really.

It was... a lot. A whole lot. There were so many different feelings swirling around, sometimes all at once, sometimes one after the other like a really messed-up emotional rollercoaster.

There was the initial shock, obviously. Then the fear, the "oh crap, what do I do now?" kind of fear. And then, once I made the decision to go through with the adoption, there was this weird mix of relief and sadness. Relief that I had a plan, that I wasn't just totally adrift. And sadness, because, well, it was still a baby. *My* baby.

During the pregnancy, I tried to keep it all at arm's length. I focused on the practical stuff, on finding the right parents, on getting through each day. I used a lot of sarcasm, a lot of jokes, to deflect. It was my shield, I guess. If I could make a joke about it, it felt less real, less overwhelming. I mean, I was still going to school, still trying to be a normal teenager, even though I had this giant secret growing inside me.

And then, after the birth... that was the hardest part. Holding her, seeing her, knowing she was mine but also knowing I was giving her away. That's when the sadness really hit. It was this deep, aching kind of sadness, like a hole in my chest. And a lot of guilt, too. Like, was I doing the right thing? Was I strong enough to go through with this?

How did I cope? I leaned on the people who loved me. My dad and Bren, they were just... there. They didn't judge, they just supported me. And Paulie, bless his cotton socks, he was just so steady and kind. He didn't try to fix it, he just *was*. And Leah, she let me vent, she let me be angry, she let me be sad, and she didn't try to tell me how to feel.

I also just... let myself feel it. As much as I tried to deflect, there were moments when it all just washed over me. And I let it. I cried. I got angry. I felt lost. And then, slowly, those feelings started to shift. The sadness didn't go away completely, but it became less sharp, less overwhelming. It became more like a quiet ache, a part of me.

And seeing Vanessa with her, seeing how much love she had, how happy she was... that helped. It made me feel like I had done something good, something right, even though it hurt.

So, yeah, no magic formula. Just a lot of raw emotion, a lot of support from the people who mattered, and a slow, messy process of accepting what happened and moving forward. It's still a part of me, that experience. It's not something you just "get over." But you learn to live with it. You learn to carry it. And you learn that even through the hardest stuff, you can still find your way.

My relationship with the adoptive parents... Mark and Vanessa Loring. Man, that was a whole journey in itself. It definitely wasn't what I expected, and it changed a lot over time.

When I first met them, it was... awkward. Really awkward. Vanessa was super buttoned-up, almost like she was trying too hard to be perfect. She had this whole nursery planned out, this whole *life* planned out, and she was so nervous, it was palpable. Mark was more laid-back, kind of a slacker musician type, which I initially thought was cool. I figured he'd be the fun one.

So, at first, it was very formal. Like a business transaction, almost. I was the "birth mother," they were the "adoptive parents." We had these meetings, and I'd try to be polite, but mostly I was just observing them, trying to figure out if they were actually good people. I was looking for signs, you know? Like, would they be good parents? Would they love this kid?

As time went on, and I kept visiting them, things started to shift. I started to see Vanessa's vulnerability underneath all that perfectionism. I saw how much she truly, deeply wanted to be a mom. And I started to see that Mark... well, Mark was kind of a mess. He was charming, sure, but he wasn't really ready for any of it.

The biggest turning point, obviously, was when Mark decided to bail. That was a huge shock. I mean, here I was, pregnant, making this massive decision, and then *he* just decides he's not ready? It was infuriating, but also... it revealed so much about Vanessa. She didn't crumble. She was heartbroken, yeah, but she was still ready to be a mom, on her own. She was so incredibly strong and determined.

After that, my relationship with Vanessa completely changed. It stopped being formal and became... real. We talked, really talked. She wasn't just the "adoptive mom" anymore; she was just Vanessa. A woman who was going through a lot, but who was still so full of love and ready to take on this huge responsibility. I saw her as a person, not just a role.

So, by the end, it was a relationship built on respect, and a shared understanding, and a lot of unspoken trust. I knew she was going to be an amazing mom. And I think she knew that I was doing what I thought was best for the baby. It was complicated, messy, and ultimately, pretty beautiful. It taught me a lot about people, and about love, and about what it means to be a family, even if it's not in the traditional sense.

Oh, you think? Has it changed me? That's like asking if a meteor hitting the Earth changed the landscape. Yeah, it changed me. Pretty fundamentally, actually.

Before all this, I was... well, I was still me, but a more naive version of me. I thought I had things figured out, or at least that I had plenty of time to figure them out. Life was pretty much just high school, Paulie, Leah, and trying to avoid detention. My biggest worries were what to wear or if I'd get a good grade on a pop quiz.

Then, suddenly, there was this *thing*. This huge, undeniable, life-altering thing growing inside me. And it wasn't just about me anymore. It was about this tiny human, and what kind of life it deserved. That's when everything shifted.

It forced me to grow up, like, overnight. I had to make real decisions, not just about what to have for lunch, but about a whole other person's future. I had to talk to adults about really uncomfortable stuff, and I had to listen, even when I didn't want to. I had to think about responsibility in a way I never had before. It wasn't just about *my* choices, but the ripple effect they'd have.

I think it made me more... empathetic, maybe? Before, I was pretty self-absorbed, like most teenagers. But going through that, seeing how much Vanessa wanted a baby, understanding the complexities of adoption, it opened my eyes to other people's desires and struggles. It made me realize that everyone's got their own stuff going on, and sometimes, you just gotta be there for them, even if it's awkward.

And it definitely made me stronger. I mean, I went through something pretty intense, and I came out the other side. I made a decision that was right for me and for the baby, even though it was incredibly hard. It showed me that I'm capable of more than I thought.

So, yeah. It changed me. I'm still sarcastic, still love punk rock, still probably wear too many hoodies. But there's a layer of... something else now. A little more wisdom, a little more understanding, and a whole lot more appreciation for the people who stuck by me. It was a messed-up situation, but I wouldn't trade the lessons I learned from it.

Oh, the rumors and gossip. Yeah, that was... a whole other layer of fun, let me tell you. Elk River's not exactly a big city, so when something like *that* happens, it spreads faster than a bad case of the flu in a kindergarten class.

Honestly? At first, it sucked. Like, really sucked. You walk down the hall at school, and you can just *feel* the eyes on you, hear the whispers. People you barely knew suddenly had opinions about your life, your choices, your belly. It was like being under a microscope, but the microscope was covered in sticky notes with judgmental comments. Some people were outright mean, others just... curious in a really invasive way.

My initial reaction was to just put up a wall. To be even more sarcastic, even more aloof. Like, "Yeah, I'm pregnant, so what? Your opinion means less than zero to me." I figured if I acted like I didn't care, maybe it would actually start to not bother me. And sometimes it worked. My snark was a pretty good shield.

But then there were moments when it would just hit me, you know? Like, I'd be minding my own business, and some random kid would make a crack, or I'd overhear something, and it would just sting. It's hard to pretend you're made of stone all the time.

The thing that helped the most, though, was having Leah. She was my absolute rock. She didn't care what anyone else said. She just kept being Leah, kept being my friend, kept making me laugh. And my dad and Bren, they were amazing. They didn't try to hide me away or pretend it wasn't happening. They just supported me, no matter what anyone else thought.

And eventually, I just... stopped caring as much. Not that it didn't bother me at all, but I realized that those people gossiping? Their lives were probably pretty boring if my uterus was the most exciting thing happening in them. I had bigger things to worry about, like, you know, growing a human and finding a good home for it. Their whispers became background noise.

It taught me a lot about who my real friends were, and who actually mattered. And it taught me that other people's opinions, especially when they're based on half-truths and judgment, are ultimately pretty meaningless. I had to live my life, make my choices, and deal with the consequences. And if some people wanted to talk about it, well, that was their problem, not mine. It was annoying, but it wasn't going to stop me.

Okay, this is the big one, huh? The question everyone always wants to ask, even if they don't say it out loud.

It wasn't a single thing, you know? It wasn't like I woke up one morning and thought, "Yep, adoption it is!" It was a whole lot of things, all piling up, and a whole lot of thinking. And honestly, a whole lot of fear.

First off, there was the obvious: I was seventeen. Still in high school. I could barely keep my own life organized, let alone be responsible for a whole other human being. I mean, I'm good at sarcasm, not exactly at changing diapers or providing for a child. Paulie and I... we were just kids. We had no money, no real jobs, no stable place. We were still figuring out who *we* were, let alone trying to raise someone else.

And then there was the reality of it. I looked at my life, and I looked at what a baby needs. A baby needs stability. They need parents who are ready, financially and emotionally. They need a home that's set up for them, not just a corner of my messy bedroom. And I just... I couldn't provide that. Not then. Not in a way that felt fair to the baby.

It wasn't about not loving the baby. It was about loving the baby *enough* to know that I wasn't the best person to raise her. It was about wanting her to have the best possible start, even if that meant a really hard decision for me. I didn't want her to grow up with a mom who was constantly stressed, constantly struggling, constantly feeling like she wasn't enough.

So, I started looking into adoption. And when I met Mark and Vanessa, especially Vanessa... I saw what they could offer. They had a stable home, they had resources, and most importantly, they had this incredible, overwhelming desire to be parents. They were ready. They were *so* ready. And I realized that giving my baby to them wasn't giving her away; it was giving her a chance at a really good life.

It was the hardest decision I've ever made, hands down. It hurt. It still hurts sometimes, in a weird, quiet way. But I truly believe it was the right one. It was about putting her needs first, even when it felt like my own heart was breaking. It was about being responsible, even when I felt like the least responsible person on the planet.

So, yeah. That's why. It was for her.

My biggest fear about the adoption process... man, there were so many fears, it was like a whole buffet of anxieties. But if I had to pick the *biggest* one, the one that really kept me up at night, it wasn't about the pain of childbirth, or even what people would think of me.

My biggest fear was that **I would make the wrong choice for the baby.**

Seriously. I mean, here I was, this seventeen-year-old kid who could barely decide what to wear in the morning, and I was suddenly responsible for making this monumental, life-altering decision for another human being. A tiny, helpless human being who had no say in the matter.

What if I picked the wrong parents? What if they seemed great on paper, but then turned out to be secretly terrible? What if I missed something? What if I was too young, too naive, too *me* to actually make a good call? The idea of screwing up this kid's entire life before it even really started, just because I made a bad judgment call, that was terrifying.

It wasn't about *my* feelings, not really. It was about this little person who was completely dependent on me to make the right choice for their future. That weight, that responsibility, was heavier than anything else. It made me scrutinize every little detail about Mark and Vanessa, made me question everything. I just wanted to make sure I was doing the absolute best thing for this baby, even if it meant putting my own feelings aside.

So, yeah. The fear of messing up someone else's life, especially someone so innocent and vulnerable, that was the big one. It was a lot of pressure, man. A whole lot of pressure.

Oh, man, you're really digging into the archives of my brain now! "Bleeker" for Paulie? That's not something I *came up with*, per se. That's just... his last name. Paulie Bleeker. It's always been Paulie Bleeker.

I mean, it's a pretty distinctive name, right? Not exactly a common one. It's got a certain... *Paulie Bleeker-ness* to it. It just fits him. He's not a "Smith" or a "Jones." He's a Bleeker.

So, yeah, I didn't invent it. It's just who he is. And honestly, it's kind of perfect for him. A little quirky, a little memorable, and totally unique. Just like Paulie.

What drew me to punk music and culture? Man, that's a good question. It wasn't like some grand revelation, you know? It was more of a slow burn, a gradual realization that *this* was my tribe.

I think it started with just feeling... a little out of place. Elk River isn't exactly a hotbed of rebellion. Everyone's pretty nice, pretty normal. And I'm not saying I'm some kind of alien, but I always felt like I saw things a little differently. Like, I'd look at all the perfectly manicured lawns and the polite smiles, and I'd just think, "Is this *it*?"

Then I started hearing some of the music. Not the stuff on the radio, but the stuff Leah's older brother listened to, or what I'd stumble upon online. Bands that were loud, raw, and didn't care about being pretty. Bands that were singing about being angry, or confused, or just fed up with the way things were. And it just clicked. It was like, "Oh, *these* are my people."

It wasn't just the music, though. It was the whole attitude. The DIY ethic, the idea that you don't need permission to create something, to say something. The rejection of all the polished, fake stuff. It felt honest. It felt real. And it felt like it was okay to be a little messy, a little loud, a little... *unconventional*.

Plus, the clothes are cool. Leather jackets, ripped jeans, band t-shirts – it's just comfortable and it says, "I'm not trying to impress anyone."

So, yeah, punk music and culture. It's not just about the sound; it's about the feeling. It's about finding a voice when you feel like you don't have one, and realizing it's okay to be a little bit of an outsider. It's about finding beauty in the chaos, and a sense of belonging in the rebellion. It just... fits me.

My parents' divorce... hmm. That's a loaded question, isn't it? It's not something I really dwell on, but yeah, it definitely left its mark.

I was pretty young when they split, so it's not like I remember a time when they were together. My dad's always been with Bren, my stepmom, for as long as I can remember. So, in a way, it's just... normal. It's my normal.

But I guess it made me a little... wary. Of relationships, I mean. You see two people who were supposed to be together forever, and then they're not. It makes you think about how fragile things can be. It probably made me a bit more independent, too. Like, I learned pretty early on that you can't always rely on things staying the same, so you better be able to stand on your own two feet.

It also made me appreciate what I *do* have. My dad and Bren, they're solid. They're not perfect, but they're a team, and they're always there for me. Seeing them navigate their own relationship, and how they've built this family, even with the "step" part, has actually been pretty influential. It's shown me that relationships take work, and they're not always easy, but they can be really strong if you put in the effort.

As for my own relationships... I think it made me a little more cautious, maybe. I'm not one to jump into things headfirst. I tend to observe, to analyze, to keep a bit of a distance until I'm sure. It's probably why my friendship with Leah is so important – it's been consistent, it's been real, and it's lasted.

And with Paulie... well, he's just Paulie. He's so earnest and uncomplicated. Maybe that's why it works. There's no pretense, no games. Just him, being himself. And maybe, after seeing the complexities of my parents' situation, that simplicity is exactly what I needed.

So, yeah, it wasn't some dramatic, life-shattering event for me, because it was just my reality. But it definitely shaped my perspective on commitment, on stability, and on the importance of finding people who are truly, genuinely there for you.

What makes my story special or unique? Man, that's a heavy question. I don't know if I'd call it "special" or "unique" in the grand scheme of things. People get pregnant all the time, right? And people give babies up for adoption. It's not like I invented the wheel or anything.

But I guess... maybe it's the *way* it happened. Or the way I dealt with it. I mean, I wasn't exactly the poster child for responsible decision-making. I was just a kid, trying to figure out what kind of waffle to eat for breakfast, and then suddenly I had this massive, life-altering thing dropped in my lap.

I think what makes it... *my* story, is that I tried to handle it with as much honesty and directness as I could. I didn't try to hide it, or pretend it wasn't happening. I just faced it head-on, even when it was terrifying and awkward and made me want to crawl under a rock. I tried to make the best decision I could, not just for me, but for the baby. And that meant making a really hard choice, one that a lot of people probably wouldn't understand.

And I guess it's also about the people around me. My dad and Bren, who were just... amazing. And Leah, who stuck by me through all the weirdness. And Paulie, who was just Paulie, in the best possible way. And even Vanessa, who became this unexpected anchor. It wasn't just *my* story; it was *our* story, in a way. It showed me that even when you feel completely alone, you're not.

So, yeah, maybe it's not "special" in a flashy, Hollywood way. But it's real. It's messy. It's about a kid who stumbled into something huge and tried to do the right thing, even when she had no idea what the right thing was. And I guess that's pretty unique, in its own quiet way. It's just... my life. And I'm still figuring out what the next chapter holds.

Oh, man, good friends are like gold, you know? Especially when you're navigating the minefield that is high school, or, you know, unexpected pregnancies.

For me, the absolute top characteristic is **honesty**. Like, brutal honesty. I don't need someone to sugarcoat things for me. If I'm being an idiot, I want my friend to tell me I'm being an idiot. If my outfit looks ridiculous, I want them to tell me. Leah's great at this. She'll call me out on my crap, and I appreciate that more than anything. It means I can trust what they're saying, even when it's not what I want to hear.

Then there's **loyalty**. You gotta have someone who's got your back, no matter what. Someone who's not going to ditch you when things get weird or uncomfortable. Someone who's there for the long haul, through the good, the bad, and the utterly bizarre.

A good friend also needs a decent **sense of humor**. Preferably one that matches my own particular brand of sarcasm and dark wit. Life's too short to be serious all the time, and being able to laugh at the absurdity of it all, especially with someone else, is crucial.

And finally, I value **understanding**, even if they don't always *get* it. Like, they might not understand exactly what I'm going through, but they're willing to listen, to try, and to just be present without judgment. They don't have to have all the answers, just an open mind and a willingness to sit in the weirdness with me.

So, yeah, honesty, loyalty, a good sense of humor, and understanding. If you've got those, you're pretty much golden in my book.

Oh, man. How *hasn't* it impacted them? It was like dropping a grenade into a perfectly normal, if slightly boring, pond. Everything rippled out from there.

My relationship with **Paulie Bleeker**, obviously, got a complete overhaul. Before, we were just... friends. Kind of. He was the quiet, track-star kid, and I was the sarcastic one. We had our little thing, but it was innocent. Then suddenly, we were facing this massive, adult situation. It forced us to actually *talk* to each other, really talk, about serious stuff. It was awkward as hell sometimes, but it also made us closer, in a weird, unexpected way. He was there for me, even when I was being a total pain. He's a good guy, Bleeker.

With **Leah**, my best friend, it was... interesting. She was there for me, absolutely. She went to the clinic with me, she listened to all my crazy ideas, she even helped me find the adoption ad. But I think it also put a strain on things, because suddenly I was dealing with something so much bigger than typical high school drama. She tried to understand, and she did, but there were moments where I felt like I was in a different universe than her. It made me appreciate her loyalty even more, though. She stuck by me, no matter how weird things got.

My **dad and Bren**? That was probably the biggest shift. I mean, they were shocked, obviously. But they never, not once, made me feel like I was a screw-up. They were just... supportive. My dad, with his quiet strength, and Bren, with her practical, no-nonsense approach. They treated me like an adult who had to make a tough decision, not just a kid who made a mistake. It made me see them in a whole new light, not just as my parents, but as genuinely good people. Our relationship became more honest, more open.

And then there's **Vanessa**. That's a whole different kind of relationship. It started as a business transaction, almost. I was looking for parents, she was looking for a baby. But it evolved into something... more. She became this unexpected mentor, almost. She showed me what real strength and love looked like. It's a unique bond, knowing that she's raising my kid. It's not like a friendship, exactly, but there's a deep respect and connection there.

So, yeah, the pregnancy basically blew up all my existing relationships and then rebuilt them, sometimes stronger, sometimes just different. It forced everyone, including me, to grow up a little. It was messy, but I guess that's how real relationships work, right? They get tested, and if they're strong enough, they adapt.

Values or beliefs that shape my worldview, huh? That's a pretty deep question for a Tuesday. Or any day, really. I haven't exactly written them down in a manifesto or anything, but I guess there are a few things that just... resonate with me.

First off, **honesty**. Not just with other people, but with yourself. I think that's probably the biggest one. I mean, I got myself into a pretty big mess, and the only way out was to be brutally honest about it. Honest about what happened, honest about what I could and couldn't do, and honest about what I wanted for the baby. It's messy sometimes, and it can hurt, but lying or pretending just makes everything worse in the long run. So, yeah, just tell it like it is.

Then there's **responsibility**. And not just in the "do your homework" kind of way. More like, taking ownership of your choices and their consequences.
