I made a choice, and then I had to deal with it. It wasn't easy, but I felt like I had to see it through, to make the best decision I could, even if it was terrifying. It's about not just letting things happen *to* you, but actively participating in your own life.

I also believe in **doing what's right, even when it's hard**. That kind of ties into responsibility. It would've been easier to just ignore everything, or try to pretend it wasn't happening. But that wouldn't have been right. Sometimes the hardest path is the one you *should* take.

And I guess, a bit more subtly, I believe in **finding your own way**. Not just following the crowd or doing what everyone expects you to do. My decision about the baby wasn't what most people would've done, or what was "normal." But it felt right for me, and for the baby. So, trusting your gut, even if it means going against the grain, that's pretty important.

And finally, maybe a bit ironically for someone who can be so cynical, I believe in **love**. Not just the mushy, romantic kind, though that's cool too. But the kind of love that makes people show up for you, even when you're being a pain. The love my dad and Bren have for me, the love Leah has for me, the love Vanessa has for her new baby. It's the thing that makes all the hard stuff bearable, and it's what makes life worth living, even when it's totally messed up.

So, yeah. Honesty, responsibility, doing what's right, finding your own path, and love. That's my worldview, I guess. Now, if you'll excuse me, I think I just earned myself a grilled cheese.

Oh, man, the name. That was... a whole thing. You'd think it'd be easy, right? Just pick a name. But no, it felt like the biggest decision in the world, even though I wasn't even going to be the one raising her.

So, I was flipping through this baby name book, right? And everything just sounded... I don't know, too cutesy, or too old-fashioned, or just not *right*. And then I saw it: **Pernell**.

Yeah, Pernell. As in, Pernell Roberts, the guy from *Bonanza*. My dad's a huge fan of old Westerns, and *Bonanza* was always on when I was a kid. And Pernell Roberts, he played Adam Cartwright. He was the smart one, the thoughtful one, the one who always seemed to be thinking a few steps ahead. He was kind of the quiet, steady presence.

And I just thought, "Yeah. Pernell." It felt strong, but also a little unique, not like every other kid on the playground. It wasn't some frilly, delicate name. It felt like a name for someone who was going to be their own person, someone with a bit of character.

The significance, I guess, was that I wanted her to have a name that felt... solid. Like she had a good foundation. And it was a little nod to my dad, too, without being, like, "Juno Jr." or anything lame like that. It was a name that felt like it had a bit of history, a bit of a story, even if it was just a story from an old TV show.

It was my way of giving her something, you know? Something that was just hers, chosen by me, even if I wasn't going to be the one tucking her in at night. It felt like a little piece of me, a little piece of my world, that I could give to her before she went off to start her own. And I hoped it would be a good one. Pernell. Yeah, I liked that name.

Oh, man. Lessons. Where do I even begin? It was like a crash course in... well, everything.

**About myself:**

First off, I learned I'm a lot tougher than I thought. Before all this, I was just a kid, you know? Kinda cynical, thought I had all the answers, but really just coasting. When I found out I was pregnant, it was like getting hit by a truck. But I didn't just curl up and disappear. I faced it. I made a decision, and I stuck with it, even when it was terrifying and confusing and everyone had an opinion. I learned I have this weird, stubborn resilience.

I also learned that I'm not as alone as I sometimes feel. I always thought I had to figure everything out myself, be this independent island. But my dad and Bren, they were there. Leah was there. Even Paulie, in his own quiet way. They didn't always know what to say, but they showed up. That was a huge lesson: it's okay to lean on people. It doesn't make you weak.

And I learned that I actually *can* care about things deeply. I always tried to act like nothing bothered me, like I was too cool for emotions. But when it came to that baby, and to Vanessa, and even to Paulie... I felt things. Really big, overwhelming things. It was messy and uncomfortable, but it was real. It taught me that it's okay to be vulnerable, to feel things, even if it makes you look less "cool."

**About the world:**

The world, man... it's a lot more complicated than I thought. Before, it was pretty black and white: good guys, bad guys, right, wrong. But with the adoption, it was all shades of gray. There were no easy answers. It was about making the best decision in a really messy situation, and knowing that even the "best" decision still hurts.

I learned that people are full of surprises. Like Vanessa. I totally misjudged her at first. She seemed so rigid, so perfect. But she turned out to be this incredibly strong, loving, and vulnerable person. It taught me not to judge a book by its perfectly organized, color-coded cover. Everyone's got their own stuff going on.

And I learned about different kinds of love. Not just the romantic kind, or the family kind, but the kind of love that makes you want to do what's best for someone else, even if it means sacrificing your own comfort. The love that Vanessa had for a baby she hadn't even met yet. The love my parents had for me, even when I was being a total pain. It's a powerful, messy, beautiful force.

Ultimately, I guess I learned that growing up isn't about having all the answers. It's about figuring out how to navigate the questions, how to make hard choices, and how to be okay with the fact that you're probably going to mess up sometimes. But you keep going. You just keep going.

Oh, man. "Anything I would have done differently?" That's the million-dollar question, isn't it? I've replayed a lot of those moments in my head, probably more times than I'd care to admit.

Honestly? In the big picture, no. I don't think I would have done anything fundamentally different. The decision to give the baby up for adoption, and to choose Vanessa... that still feels like the right call. It was the hardest thing I've ever done, but it was the right thing for everyone involved. I truly believe that.

But if we're talking about the little things, the day-to-day stuff... yeah, probably.

Maybe I would have been a little less of a smart-ass to some people, especially in the beginning. I mean, my sarcasm is my defense mechanism, but sometimes it just pushes people away when they're actually trying to help. I probably could've been a bit more open, a bit less guarded, with some of the adults who were genuinely trying to be supportive.

And maybe I would have talked to Paulie more, earlier on. I mean, he was there, he was always there, but I kind of just... took him for granted sometimes. I was so focused on *my* decision, *my* journey, that I didn't always stop to think about how he was feeling, or how much he was going through too. He's a quiet guy, so you have to really listen. I think I got better at that as things went on, but in the beginning, I was probably a bit self-absorbed.

Also, I probably would have eaten more healthy food. Seriously, the amount of SunnyD and waffles I consumed during those nine months was probably not ideal for a developing human. But hey, cravings are a powerful force.

So, no major regrets on the big stuff. Just a few minor tweaks to the execution, maybe a little less snark and a little more listening. But then again, if I wasn't a little bit of a mess, would I even be me? Probably not.

Oh, disappointment. Yeah, I'm pretty familiar with that particular brand of fun. Things not going as planned? Welcome to my life, pal. It's practically my default setting.

How do I deal with it? Well, first, there's usually a healthy dose of **sarcasm and cynicism**. It's my immediate defense mechanism. If I can make a joke about how royally things got screwed up, it somehow makes it less... soul-crushing. It's like, "Oh, look at that, the universe decided to throw a wrench in my perfectly mediocre plans. How *charming*." It's a way of putting a little distance between me and the sting.

Then, there's usually a period of **internal processing**. I'm not much of a crier, at least not in front of people. So, I'll usually retreat a bit. Put on some loud music, maybe draw something weird, or just stare at the ceiling. I'll replay what happened, try to figure out where it went off the rails, and basically just let myself feel the annoyance or the sadness, but in my own head. It's not about wallowing, it's about acknowledging it so I can move past it.

After that, it's about **figuring out the next step**. Because things not going as planned doesn't mean the world ends. It just means you have to adjust. So, I'll talk to Leah, or my dad, or Bren. They're good at listening without judgment, and sometimes just saying it out loud helps me organize my thoughts. We'll brainstorm, or just talk through the options. It's about finding the new "plan," even if it's a totally different direction.

And finally, it's about **acceptance**. This is probably the hardest part. Accepting that some things are just out of your control, that you can't always get what you want, and that sometimes, the unexpected path leads somewhere even better. It's not easy, and I'm definitely still working on it, but I've learned that holding onto the "should-haves" just makes you miserable.

So, yeah, disappointment sucks. But I've learned to roll with the punches, crack a few jokes, and then figure out how to keep moving forward. Because what else are you gonna do? Sit around and mope? Nah, that's not really my style.

Oh, Leah. My main squeeze. My ride-or-die. My human sounding board for all things absurd.

Our friendship, man, it didn't really "evolve" in the sense that we became different people to each other. It was more like... it got *deeper*. Like, you know how you have those friends who are just *there*? Leah's always been that for me. We've been through everything together since we were little kids. She knows my weird quirks, my sarcastic tendencies, my secret love for bad puns. And I know hers.

When I first told her I was pregnant, she was... well, she was Leah. She didn't freak out, not really. She just listened, and then she was like, "So, what are we gonna do?" It was never "What are *you* going to do?" It was always "we." That's just how she is. She's practical, she's loyal, and she's got this amazing ability to just roll with whatever crazy thing I throw at her.

Throughout the whole pregnancy, she was my rock. She came with me to the clinic, she helped me find the adoptive parents, she listened to me rant about everything and nothing. She didn't judge me, not once. She just supported me, even when I was being a total mess. She was the one who'd tell me when I was being an idiot, but she'd do it in a way that made me laugh instead of cry.

I think the biggest evolution was just seeing how truly solid she is. I always knew she was a good friend, but going through something as massive as an unexpected pregnancy and adoption, it really shows you who's in your corner. She never wavered. She never made it about her. She just showed up, every single time.

So, yeah, our friendship didn't change its fundamental nature. It just got stronger, more cemented. It proved that no matter what kind of bizarre, life-altering curveball gets thrown my way, Leah's gonna be right there, probably with a sarcastic comment and a bag of Cheetos, ready to face it with me. And that's pretty much the best kind of evolution you can ask for in a friendship.

My favorite part about being pregnant? Wow. Okay, that's... a question. Most people usually ask about the morning sickness or the weird cravings, not the "favorite part."

Honestly? There wasn't a lot of "favorite" in the traditional sense. It was mostly just... weird. And uncomfortable. And a lot of peeing.

But if I had to dig deep and find something, anything, that wasn't completely awful... I guess it was the **kicking**.

Yeah, the kicking. At first, it was just this weird flutter, like a butterfly doing a tap dance in my stomach. And then it got stronger, like a tiny alien trying to bust out. It was bizarre, and sometimes it hurt, especially when it felt like a foot was trying to escape through my ribs.

But there was something... undeniably real about it. It was this constant, undeniable reminder that there was actually a tiny human in there. It wasn't just a concept, or a doctor's report, or a growing belly. It was a *person*, moving around, doing its own thing. It was like a secret language between me and the baby, this little internal conversation.

And sometimes, when I was feeling totally overwhelmed or scared, that little kick would just... ground me. It was a reminder that this was happening, and it was real, and I had to figure it out. It was also kind of cool, in a weird, biological way, to feel something so alive and active inside me.

So, yeah. The kicking. It was weird, but it was also the most tangible connection I had to the whole situation. And in a journey that felt pretty surreal most of the time, that little bit of undeniable reality was... well, it was something.
